GRASSHOPPER COMPONENT REFERENCE
Generated for this specific installation.
---
## Bake Objects
   (Tab: Elefront > Panel: 06 Bake)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to bake"
   - A [Attributes]: "Attributes to assign to baked geometry"
   - N [BakeName]: "If specified, all objects that were previously baked with the same Bake Name will be deleted! Only supports single item input. Do not assign different Bake Names to different branches. Use Key/Value pair to assign different attributes to each branch."
   - B [Bake]: "Activate. Bake all objects to Rhino"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Message]: "Status Message"
   - G [Guids]: "Guids of Baked Geometry"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Transforms
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - X [Transforms]: "Set of transforms to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Transform at X start, 1.0 = Transform at X end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Transform at index 0, Index number of last transform = Transform at last index)

The tween factor range from one transform to the next transform in the list is:
Index number of a transform = the transform at that index, Index number of the next transform = the next transform in the list, factors between the transform index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween transform halfway between the transform at index 2 and the transform at index 3."
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween transform"

----------------------------------------

## Curves Region Offset
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Planar closed curves"
   - O [Offset]: "Offset distance"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Position Tolerance for finding the planes and converting curves to polylines"
   - A [AngleTolerance]: "Angle Tolerance for plane"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Curves as polylines grouped by region"
   - Co [Curves Out]: "Curves offseted OUT grouped by region, contour are offseted positively and holes negatively"
   - Ci [Curves In]: "Curves offseted IN grouped by region, contour are offseted negatively and holes positively"
   - P [Planes]: "Planes for each region"

## Tween Through Planes On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, numbers between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on curve"

----------------------------------------

## Surface Edit Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to get the edit points of"
   - K [Knots]: "If True, only the edit points at knots (span ends) are extracted (the points an interpolated surface interpolated through)
If False, all edit points are extracted which equals the same amount as the surface control points"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Edit points on the surface"
   - N [Normals]: "Normal vectors at edit points"
   - U [Count U]: "Number of edit points along the surface {u} direction"
   - V [Count V]: "Number of edit points along the surface {v} direction"
   - uv [Parameters]: "Parameter coordinates at edit points"

   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Circles]: "Circles in XY plane"
   - S [SortCircles]: "Sort the list of overlapping circles, 0 no change in the list, -1 sort radius descending,  1 sort radius ascending, , 2 sort X of the center ascending, 3 sort Y of the center ascending"
   - T [Tolerance]: "If tolerance is positive thats allows circles to intersect a bit, if negative circles will not touch at all"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Circles]: "Circles"

## Tween Through Planes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Plane at Pl start, Factor 1.0 = Plane at Pl end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane"

## Mirror Combine Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Colors]: "Set of colors to mirror combine"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (false = End of set, true = Start of set)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror combined color set (removes the duplicate color in the middle of the set)"
   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the color set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"
   - a [Alpha]: "Invert the transparencies (alpha values) of the mirrored colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirrored]: "Resulting mirror combined color set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror combined color set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."

## Export 3DM
   (Tab: Pancake > Panel: 02 | Output)

   INPUTS:
   - Geo [Geometry]: "The geometry you want to export"
   - Layer [Layer]: "Layer to put the geometries. By default, this input will override ObjAttr."
   - ObjAttr [Object Attributes]: "Object attributes. Layer in this structure isn't used by default, right click the component to change the behavior.
You may use Object attributes from Elefront, or Human.
See manual for supported attributes."
   - File [File Location]: "Where to store the file. Filename and extension should be included."
   - Overwrite [Overwrite]: "Default false. Control if Pancake should overwrite the destination file."
   - Ver [Version]: "The version of 3dm file. Can be 2 to the current version, or 0 as the latest version. 0 by default."
   - Export [Export]: "Set to True to conduct the export. Use True - only button or Toggle button. Do not use the vanilla button."

   OUTPUTS:
   - OK [OK]: "Returns if the action is successful"
   - Log [Log]: "Log, if available"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curves on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Bake Geometry
   (Tab: Human > Panel: Creation)

   INPUTS:
   - bake [Bake?]: "Set to true to bake objects to the document with the specified attributes. This component is designed for regular Grasshopper geometry - if you have special objects to bake, such as lights, hatches, or blocks, use their dedicated creation components."
   - geo [Geometry]: "The Grasshopper geometry to bake"
   - att [Attributes]: "The Attributes to assign the geometry"

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

----------------------------------------

## Weighted Average Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves for averaging"
   - W [Weights]: "Collection of weights for each curve"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped averages, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped averages, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input curves"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at S start, 1.0 = Surface at S end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Surface at index 0, Index number of last surface = Surface at last index)

The tween factor range from one surface to the next surface in the list is:
Index number of a surface = the surface at that index, Index number of the next surface = the next surface in the list, factors between the surface index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween surface halfway between the surface at index 2 and the surface at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input surface set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surface"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array through"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domain (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domain (0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through surfaces {w} domain (0.0 = {w}Surface at index 0, Index number of last surface = {w}Surface at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last surface, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Planes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl, 1.0 = Plane at Pl +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input plane set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween planes"

----------------------------------------

To split the mirrored combined transform set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."

## Render Curve to Screen
   (Tab: Human > Panel: Display)

   INPUTS:
   - Crv [Curve]: "Curve to display to screen. Make sure the curve is positioned at (or near) the world origin."
   - L [Location]: "The location to display the text. If "Scale With Viewport" is unchecked, specify points in pixel coordinates - 
 100,100,0 will be 100 pixels right and down from the upper-left corner of the viewport."
   - S [Scale Factor]: "A multiplier on the scale. Use this to adjust the size of the curve in the display."
   - C [Color]: "The color to display the Curve. "
   - T [Thickness]: "The lineweight to display the curve. "
   - D [Depth]: "A value between 0-1 that controls the Z-depth of the curve display. 
A high number will appear in front of most objects - low will go behind.
However, values exactly equal to 0 or 1 should be avoided - stay slightly within the 
limits to avoid artifacts"
   - F [Fixed]: "If true, objects remain fixed, oriented to the screen plane - if false, objects rotate when the viewport does."

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

----------------------------------------

   - B [Back]: "Boolean indicating whether the point is to the back of the surface (also true if point is on surface)"
   - D [Distance]: "Distance between the point and surface (Negative distance = Back of Surface, Positive distance = Front of Surface)"

   - Pahr [dataAngleHeightRadius]: "Parameter of the arc, an angle (in degree), an height or a radius"

   - B [Color B]: "Color to tween to"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Color A, 1.0 = Color B)"

   OUTPUTS:

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Curve at C start, Factor 1.0 = Curve at C end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Scatter Area Modifier
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Scatter)

   INPUTS:
   - • V Geo [• V Geometry]: "Specifies objects to be used for generating projected areas of exclusion or inclusion of Scatter guests. These areas are projected along specified axes and determined by the dimensions of objects or splines included in this list. Scatter Area Modifier objects cannot be the same as the Scatter Host objects."
   - Falloff [Falloff]: "Determines the distance from the selected area modifier object where the falloff range begins its effect. The falloff range is the gradual transition of the area modifier effect between 100% and 0%."
   - Scale [Scale]: "Scale factor affecting instances with the Falloff range. The value represents the effect strength at the end of the falloff range. For example, a value of 0.5 causes instances to have a scale of 0% at beginning of the range gradually increasing to 50% at end. Note that that a value of 0 negates the falloff effect altogether."
   - Density [Density]: "Density factor affecting instances within the Falloff range. The value represents the effect strength at the end of the falloff range. For example, a value of 0.5 causes instances to appear at a density of 0% at the beginning of the range gradually increasing to 50% at the end. Note that that a value of 0 negates the falloff effect altogether."
   - Axis [Axis]: "Determines the plane of the area modifier projection along the X, Y or Z axis."
   - Operation [Operation]: "Specifies the Scatter distribution relative to the Area modifier objects. Include - only instances within the projected area are created. Exclude - only instances outside the projected area are created."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Area Modifier [• Area Modifier]: "Scatters Guest objects everywhere on the Host objects, except for or exclusively in the areas specified by a V-Ray Area Modifier component. Can be connected to the V-Ray Scatter 2 component’s Area Modifiers input."

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Consecutive Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to create twisted box array between"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between each meshes {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Mesh at M, {w}1.0 = Mesh at M +1)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the parameters {w} interpolation path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between meshes"

## Parameter Extrude Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Profile]: "Profile curve to extrude as mesh"
   - D [Direction]: "Extrusion direction vector, curve, or point

Input a vector to exrude along a vector
Input a curve to exrude along a curve
Input a point to extrude to a point"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along profile curve {u} domain for mesh faces ({u}0.0 = Profile start, {u}1.0 = Profile end)
(unless Length is true or Angle is not 0.0)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along extrusion direction {v} domain for mesh faces ({v}0.0 = Extrusion start, {v}1.0 = Extrusion end)
(unless length {v} is true or angle {v} is not 0.0 while using a curve for extrusion direction)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the profile curves curvature"
   - L [Lengths]: "If True, profile curves mesh face divisions are defined by the lengths between its control points instead of the {u} parameters

(useful for conforming mesh face divisions to each segment of a polyline profile curve)"
   - A [Angle]: "If Angle is not 0.0, profile curves mesh face divisions are defined by angle accuracy in degrees instead of the {u} parameters

(useful for conforming mesh face divisions to the curvature of the profile curve)"
   - C [Cap]: "Cap the open ends of a closed profile curve mesh extrusion"
   - T [Triangulate]: "Triangulate the mesh faces"
   - vW [Weighted V]: "If True, parameters {v} distribution is weighted by the extrusion direction curves curvature if a curve is used for the extrusion direction"
   - vL [Lengths V]: "If True, extrusion direction curves mesh face divisions are defined by the lengths between its control points instead of the {v} parameters if a curve is used for the extrusion direction

(useful for conforming mesh face divisions to each segment of a polyline extrusion direction curve)"
   - vA [Angle V]: "If Angle is not 0.0, extrusion direction curves mesh face divisions are defined by angle accuracy in degrees instead of the {v} parameters if a curve is used for the extrusion direction

(useful for conforming mesh face divisions to the curvature of the extrusion direction curve)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - E [Extruded]: "Resulting extrude mesh"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Clipper
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Geometry)

   INPUTS:
   - Clip Mode [Clip Mode]: "When set to Subtract (1) everything inside the specified mesh is clipped away (only for mesh clippers).
When set to Intersect (0) everything outside the specified mesh is clipped away."
   - Geo [Geo]: "Expects either a plane, mesh or any other geometric object input (including V-Ray Geometry).
A closed mesh should be used for best results."
   - Use Object Mtl [Use Object Mtl]: "When enabled, the clipper will use the material of each clipped object to fill the resulting cuts.
When disabled, the material applied to the clipper object itself will be used.
If no material is specified in this state, the clipped gaps remain empty."
   - • Mtl [• Material]: "V-Ray Material input expected."
   - Excl. Mode [Exclusion Mode]: "When set to Exclude(1) all scene objects will be clipped except for those in the Exclusion List.
When set to Include (0) only the listed objects will be clipped."
   - • Exclude [• Exclude]: "When set to Exclude(1) all scene objects will be clipped except for those in the Exclusion List.
When set to Include (0) only the listed objects will be clipped."
   - Affect Light [Affect Light]: "When enabled, light can pass through openings created by the clipper."
   - Cam. Rays Only [Camera Rays Only]: "When enabled, clipped objects will appear unaffected in reflections, refractions and GI."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • V Geo [• V Geometry]: "A V-Ray Geometry output that can be connected to the V-Ray Render component."

----------------------------------------

If you choose left-aligned, the tag line will extend out to the right."
   - F [Font Name]: "The name of the font to use"
   - FS [Font Size]: "The size of the text font"

   - LW [Line Weight]: "The weight of the line"

## Twisted Box Through Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to create twisted box array through"
   - T [Thickness]: "Overall thickness of the twisted box array, offset from the curves"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters through curves {u} domain ({u}0.0 = Curve at C start, {u}1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along curve {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Curve starts, {v}1.0 = Curve ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Curves, {w}1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for {u} parameters are ({u}0.0 = Curve at index 0, {u}Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last curve, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is evaluated along the interpolation path without considering the locations of the input curve set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {v} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvatures"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the parameters {u} interpolation path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the division parameters {u} range maximum by 1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {u} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through curves"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Planes On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, numbers between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on surface"

## Tween Through Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curve on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last point = Curve at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Curve at C start, Factor 1.0 = Curve at C end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve on surface"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:

   - t [Parameters]: "Parameter values at division points"

   - Tolerance [Tolerance]: "Points closer than this distance will be combined into a single particle"
   - Damping [Damping]: "Value between 0 and 1, for how much velocity is preserved between iterations"

   - On [On]: "If true, Kangaroo will continue to iterate until reaching the given threshold value"

   INPUTS:

   - D [Distance]: "The list of distanced to use in the construction of the new internal vertices. One distance/vertex"
   - T [OffsetType]: "Definition of distance for new vertices

0: Distance On Diagonals. The measurement on the diagonal decides the offset.
1: Hypotenuse Average. Trigonometrical. This setting is experimental..
2: Planes Intersections. Planes intersections, works best with valence-three vertices. This setting is experimental.."

   (Tab: Wb > Panel: SubD)

   - L [Level]: "The number of subdividing iterations for each face"
   - S [Smooth Naked Edges]: "Defines how to treat the naked edges

0: Fixed. Naked edges will not move or be modified.
1: Smooth. The naked edge will tend toward a spline.
2: Corner Fixed. Corners (2-sided vertices) will be fixed, while other naked vertices will tend toward a spline.
"

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [Output Mesh/Curves]: "The mesh after the subdividing process"

## Twisted Box Pipe
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box pipe array around"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, the parameters {u} input is used as normalized lengths (0.5 = Curve middle).
If False, the parameters {u} input is used as curve parameters. (0.5 = Domain middle)."
   - D [Diameter]: "Outer diameter of the twisted box pipe array"
   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the twisted box pipe array, offset inward from the outer diameter corners"
   - R [Rotation]: "Rotation around curve of the twisted box pipe array, in degrees"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

## Tween Through Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween through"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Two Way Domain²
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - uE [Extent U]: "Number which will be the negative and positive {u} extents of the domain² from zero"
   - vE [Extent V]: "Number which will be the negative and positive {v} extents of the domain² from zero"
   - D [Direction]: "If True, the domain² is increasing (negative to positive)
If False, the domain² is decreasing (positive to negative)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - I² [Domain²]: "Resulting two way domain²"

----------------------------------------

## Weaverbird's Mesh Antiprism
   (Tab: Wb > Panel: Define)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Plane]: "A plane used to form the base of the solid"
   - W [Width]: "The base circle width"
   - S [NumberOfSides]: "The number of sides of the base polygon"
   - T [TopPoint]: "The point defining the top of the solid"
   - C [BasePolygonMethod]: "True: the width refers to the radius of the circumscribed circle
False: the width refers to the inscribed circle"
   - F [FillStrategy]: "The filling strategy

0: Skip. No insertions at the targeted faces.
1: Best. Use the best combination available today.
2: Triangle Fan. A fan of triangles, with an addition center point.
3: Triangle Hand. A series of triangles, all pointing towards vertex zero.
4: Triangle Knit. Triangles start from vertex 0 and follow in rectangular way.
5: Triangle Zigzag. Triangles start from vertex 0 and alternate.
6: Quad Stitch. Lays quads except in last segment if it is odd.
7: Quad Fan. Adds a central point and positions quads every two edges."

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [OutMesh]: "The resulting mesh ()"

----------------------------------------

   INPUTS:

   - S [NumberOfSides]: "The number of sides of the base polygon"

   - C [BasePolygonMethod]: "True: the width refers to the radius of the circumscribed circle

0: Skip. No insertions at the targeted faces.
1: Best. Use the best combination available today.
2: Triangle Fan. A fan of triangles, with an addition center point.
3: Triangle Hand. A series of triangles, all pointing towards vertex zero.
4: Triangle Knit. Triangles start from vertex 0 and follow in rectangular way.
5: Triangle Zigzag. Triangles start from vertex 0 and alternate.
6: Quad Stitch. Lays quads except in last segment if it is odd.
7: Quad Fan. Adds a central point and positions quads every two edges."

   - L [Luminosity Type]: "Determines which common grayscale luminosity weighting scheme to use

0 = R*0.2989, G*0.5870, B*0.1140
1 = R*0.2627, G*0.6780, B*0.0593
2 = R*0.2126, G*0.7152, B*0.0722
3 = R*0.3333, G*0.3333, B*0.3333"

## Tween Through Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Mesh at M start, 1.0 = Mesh at M end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Mesh at index 0, Index number of last mesh = Mesh at last index)

The tween factor range from one mesh to the next mesh in the list is:
Index number of a mesh = the mesh at that index, Index number of the next mesh = the next mesh in the list, factors between the mesh index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween mesh halfway between the mesh at index 2 and the mesh at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input mesh set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween mesh"

----------------------------------------

   - ObjAttr [Object Attributes]: "Object attributes. Layer in this structure isn't used by default, right click the component to change the behavior.
You may use Object attributes from Elefront, or Human.
See manual for supported attributes."
   - File [File Location]: "Where to store the file. Filename and extension should be included."
   - Overwrite [Overwrite]: "Default false. Control if Pancake should overwrite the destination file."
   - Export [Export]: "Set to True to conduct the export. Use True - only button or Toggle button. Do not use the vanilla button."

   OUTPUTS:
   - OK [OK]: "Returns if the action is successful"

## Viewport Properties
   (Tab: Human > Panel: Document Info)

   INPUTS:
   - U [Update]: "Toggle this to force an update when autoupdate is not active."
   - AU [Auto Update]: "Set to true to listen for certain changes to viewports. It will update the component when the active viewport changes, or when viewports are added, destroyed, or renamed."

   OUTPUTS:
   - VP [Viewport Names]: "The list of viewports"
   - I [Active Viewport Index]: "The index of the currently active viewport"
   - B [Viewport Bounds]: "A rectangle for each viewport"
   - DM [Viewport Display Mode]: "The english name of the display mode for each viewport"
   - CL [Camera Location]: "The location of the camera in each viewport"
   - CT [Camera Target]: "The location of the camera target in each viewport"
   - CP [Camera Plane]: "The camera plane for each viewport"
   - CLL [Camera Lens Length]: "The 35mm lens length of the camera in each viewport"
   - CPr [Camera Projection]: "True if the camera is a perspective projection"
   - CU [Camera Up]: "The up vector for the camera in each viewport"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curve on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Random Split List
   (Tab: LunchBox > Panel: Util)

   INPUTS:
   - L [Master List]: "A list to randomly split."
   - R [Seed]: "Random seed value."
   - S [Split]: "A value between 0 and 1."

   OUTPUTS:
   - A [List A]: "List A after the split."
   - B [List B]: "List B after the split."

----------------------------------------

   - L1 Regularization [L1 Regularization]: "The L1 regularization weight."
   - L2 Regularization [L2 Regularization]: "The L2 regularization weight."
   - History Size [History Size]: "Number of previous iterations to remember for estimating the Hessian. Lower values mean faster but less accurate estimates."
   - Tolerance [Optimization Tolerance]: "Tolerance parameter for optimization convergence. (Low = slower, more accurate)."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Trainer Type [Trainer Type]: "The trainer used for machine learning problems."

The decimal places of this number can only be displayed up until the amount set in Grasshopper's formatting options (File>Preferences>Display>Formatting), those settings only change how a number is displayed, they do not change the actual value of the number itself. Additionally, unecessary trailing zeros won't be displayed because of Grasshopper."

   (Tab: Display > Panel: Colour)

   INPUTS:

   - M [Magenta]: "Magenta channel (magenta is defined in the range {0.0 to 1.0})"
   - Y [Yellow]: "Yellow channel (yellow is defined in the range {0.0 to 1.0})"
   - K [Key]: "Key channel (key is defined in the range {0.0 to 1.0})"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Colour]: "Resulting colour"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Plane]: "World XY plane"

## Environment Fog
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Environment)

   INPUTS:
   - Color [Fog Color]: "Defines the color of the fog when it is illuminated by the light sources."
   - Emission [Fog Emission]: "Controls the fog emission (self-illumination).
You can use this parameter to substitute ambient illumination inside the fog, instead of using GI."
   - Distance [Fog Distance]: "Controls the fog density. 
Larger values make the fog more transparent, while smaller values make it denser."
   - Height [Fog Height]: "The fog starts at this level in Z axis and continues downwards indefinitely."
   - Scatter GI [Scatter GI]: "Enables the fog to scatter global illumination.
Note that this can be quite slow."
   - Affected Type [Affected Lights Type]: "Determines which scene lights affect the fog."
   - • Lights [• Affected Lights]: "List of Lights to affect the fog."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Volumetric [• Environment Volume]: "Environment volume shader"

## Twisted Box Pipe Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Pipe-like surface to create twisted boxes along the inside of"
   - u¹ [Parameters U1]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v1} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - u² [Parameters U2]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v2} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - u³ [Parameters U3]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v3} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - u⁴ [Parameters U4]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v4} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - v¹ [Parameter V1]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the first and fifth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the lowest number of the {v} parameters"
   - v² [Parameter V2]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the second and sixth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v1} but a lower number than parameter {v3}"
   - v³ [Parameter V3]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the third and seventh corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v2} but a lower number than parameter {v4}"
   - v⁴ [Parameter V4]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the fourth and eigth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the largest number of the {v} parameters"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distributions are weighted by the input pipe-like surface curvature"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the twisted box flow if they are not flowing in the correct direction along the the inside of the pipe-like surface"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along the inside of the pipe-like surface"

----------------------------------------

## Round To Factor
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Number)

   INPUTS:
   - x [Number X]: "Number to round"
   - f [Factor]: "Multiplication factor to round to"
   - T [Round Type]: "Determines how the number is rounded

0 = Nearest
1 = Floor
2 = Ceiling"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Rounded]: "Resulting rounded number from rounding x to the multiplication factor

The decimal places of this number can only be displayed up until the amount set in Grasshopper's formatting options (File>Preferences>Display>Formatting), those settings only change how a number is displayed, they do not change the actual value of the number itself. Additionally, unecessary trailing zeros won't be displayed because of Grasshopper."
   - D [Difference]: "The difference between the resulting rounded number and the input number x"
   - rM [Multiplier R]: "The number of times the multiplication factor fits into the resulting rounded number"
   - xM [Multiplier X]: "The number of times the multiplication factor fits into the input number x"

## Average Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces for averaging"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped averages, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped averages, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Colors]: "Set of colors to mirror cut"
   - Mi [Mirror Index]: "Index that the kept side of the color set cut gets mirrored across.
Negative index reverses the color set and removes from the top."
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (false = Mirror after index, true = Mirror before index)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut color set (removes the duplicate color in the middle of the set)"
   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the color set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"
   - a [Alpha]: "Invert the transparencies (alpha values) of the mirrored colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut color set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut color set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mirror index intersected the color set, False if the mirror index did not intersect the color set"

----------------------------------------

   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"

   OUTPUTS:

## Platonic Tetrahedron
   (Tab: LunchBox > Panel: Form)

   INPUTS:
   - Pln [Plane]: "Orientation plane."
   - Rad [Radius]: "Spherical radius."
   - Trunc [Truncation]: "The truncation parameter (a value between 0 and 1)."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Plato [Platonic Solid]: "The platonic solid"

----------------------------------------

## Holes in Brep
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Various)

   INPUTS:

   - T [Tol]: "Tolerance"
   - F [Filter]: "If true, holes are filtered according to the ratio (0 far from a perfect cylinder, 1 a perfect cylinder"
   - R [Ratio]: "Ratio"

   OUTPUTS:

   - P1 [Plane1]: "Plane that is on the bottom of the hole is hole is not both side"
   - R [Radius]: "Radius"
   - B [IsBothSide]: "True is hole is both side"
   - P [IsPartial]: "True is hole is not a perfect cylinder"
   - Ra [Ratio]: "Ratio of cylindrical surface over perfect cylinder surface"
   - A [Axis]: "Axis as Line"

## Twisted Box Two Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Curve A]: "Curve to create twisted box array from"
   - B [Curve B]: "Curve to create twisted box array to"
   - T [Thickness]: "Overall thickness of the twisted box array, offset from the curves"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters between curves {u} domain ({u}0.0 = Curve A, {u}1.0 = Curve B)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along curve {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Curve starts, {v}1.0 = Curve ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Curves, {w}1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {v} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvatures"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array between curves"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, numbers between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve"

----------------------------------------

## Rotate Euler
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to rotate"
   - Pl [Plane]: "Intial base plane the rotation starts from"
   - A¹ [Axis 1]: "The first plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - A² [Axis 2]: "The second plane axis to rotate around, derived from the plane rotated around axis 1

0 = {x} of the plane rotated around axis 1
1 = {y} of the plane rotated around axis 1
2 = {z} of the plane rotated around axis 1"
   - A³ [Axis 3]: "The third plane axis to rotate around, derived from the plane rotated around axis 2

0 = {x} of the plane rotated around axis 2
1 = {y} of the plane rotated around axis 2
2 = {z} of the plane rotated around axis 2"
   - D¹ [Degrees 1]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 1 (α)"
   - D² [Degrees 2]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 2 (β)"
   - D³ [Degrees 3]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 3 (γ)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Rotated]: "Resulting rotated geometry"
   - Pl¹ [Plane 1]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 1 (axis 1 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - Pl² [Plane 2]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 2 (axis 2 is an axis from plane 1)"
   - Pl³ [Plane 3]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 3 (axis 3 is an axis from plane 2)"
   - X [Transform]: "Transformation data"

----------------------------------------

## Close Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:

   - T [Close Type]: "Determines how the curve is closed

0 = Linear
1 = Tangency
2 = Curvature
3 = Meet Ends"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for curve closing segment"
   - t [Tolerance]: "Optional allowable distance between start and end of curve.
If gap is larger than tolerance the curve will not close.
If tolerance is 0 the curve will close no matter the gap size."

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Closed]: "Resulting closed curve"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if open curve was closed, False if curve did not close or already was closed"

## Mirror Cut SubD
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: SubD)

   INPUTS:
   - SD [SubD]: "SubD to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the SubD cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the SubD within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the SubD from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut SubD"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the SubD and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut SubDs are connected (0 = Split faces, with connection, 1 = Remove faces, with connection, 2 = Shrink faces, with connection, 3 = Split faces, without connection, 4 = Remove faces, without connection, 5 = Shrink faces, without connection)"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut SubD connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"
   - D [Divisions]: "Number of SubD edge loop divisions per side of the SubD connection"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld SubD vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother (0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"
   - Cr [Crease Type]: "Determines how SubDs are creased (0 = None, 1 = At Creases, 2 = At Edges)"
   - Co [Corner Type]: "Determines how SubDs are cornered (0 = None, 1 = At Corners)"
   - Iv [Interpolate Vertices]: "If True, SubDs are interpolated through their control polygon vertices"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut SubDs"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false). To split the mirror cut SubD set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the SubD was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the SubD was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array through"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surfaces start, {u}1.0 = Surfaces end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surfaces start, {v}1.0 = Surfaces end)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface at S start, {w}1.0 = Surface at S end), unless Normalized is False

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for {w} parameters are ({w}0.0 = Surface at index 0, {w}Index number of last surface = Surface at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last surface, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is evaluated along the interpolation path without considering the locations of the input surface set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween through"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the guides between the curve extremes without considering the locations of the input curve set"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points)

## Slide Curve Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to slide along guide curve"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to slide along"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to slide along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Slide factor (0.0 = Slide start, 1.0 = Slide end)"
   - A [Align]: "Align with slide curve to the input curve to slide, when using one guide curve"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped slides, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped slides, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Slide]: "Resulting slide curve along curve"

## Mesh Iso Splitting to Meshes Ext
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh"
   - Wv [Weigts Vertices]: "Weigts on Vertices, a double for each vertex of the mesh"
   - I [Iso Values]: "Iso values, if not value, median value is choosen"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance"
   - P [Parallel]: "If true parallel calculation"
   - P [Power]: "Power for the inverse distance weighting calculation [-4 4]"
   - S [Seed]: "Seed for the random colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Iso Split Meshes"

----------------------------------------

## Angle Dimension (Points)
   (Tab: Rhino > Panel: Annotations)

   INPUTS:
   - Angle Dimension [Angle Dimension]: "The Rhino anglular dimension"
   - Center [Center]: "Angle center point"
   - Point A [Point A]: "End of the first angle direction"
   - Point B [Point B]: "End of the second angle direction"
   - Dimension Location [Dimension Location]: "A point on the dimension line."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Angle Dimension [Angle Dimension]: "The Rhino anglular dimension"
   - Center [Center]: "Angle center point"
   - Point A [Point A]: "End of the first angle direction"
   - Point B [Point B]: "End of the second angle direction"
   - Dimension Location [Dimension Location]: "A point on the dimension line."

## Tween Consecutive Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P, 1.0 = Point at P +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input point set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween points"

----------------------------------------

## Internalize
   (Tab: Pancake > Panel: Internal)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Component]: "Component filter. Empty by default. When parameter is not empty, only geometries referenced by these components will be internalized."
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry filter. Empty by default. When the parameter is not empty, any geometry outside the list will not be internalized."
   - D [Delete]: "False by default. If this is true, internalized geometries will be removed from the Rhino document. You must follow guidelines when using this feature to avoid crashing Grasshopper. See manual for details."
   - OK [OK]: "Set this to true to internalize geometries."

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

## Tween Through Planes On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl start, 1.0 = Plane at Pl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input plane set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input plane set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Noise on Mesh
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh"
   - S [Scale]: "Scale coefficient, it is like a frequency, 1 is like Sinus(x), 0.1 is like Sinus(x*0.1) "
   - T [Time]: "Time"
   - D [Details]: "Number of octave (scale multiplied by 2 each time)"
   - R [Roughness]: "Roughness factor between 0 and 1.0"
   - Seed [Seed]: "Seed"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Grey mesh"
   - Wv [Output Noise]: "Output values (Veights) of noise [0, 1] on each mesh Vertex"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Mesh at M start, 1.0 = Mesh at M end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Mesh at index 0, Index number of last mesh = Mesh at last index)

The tween factor range from one mesh to the next mesh in the list is:
Index number of a mesh = the mesh at that index, Index number of the next mesh = the next mesh in the list, factors between the mesh index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween mesh halfway between the mesh at index 2 and the mesh at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input mesh set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - C [Colored Type]: "Determines how mesh vertex colors are tweened

0 = None
1 = Fast
2 = Accurate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween mesh"

----------------------------------------

## Flow on Mesh along Vectors
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: CurveOnMesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh"
   - Vv [Vectors]: "A Vector for each vertex of the mesh"
   - P [Points]: "Points to start from (must not be at distance more than 10 to the mesh)"
   - N [Samples]: "Number of samples (parts of curve on mesh)"
   - R [Reverse]: "If true will calculate the descending and climbing trajectories"
   - E [Epsilon]: "A relative tolerance "

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Curve approximation of field line through P"

----------------------------------------

## Cut Mesh And Rotate
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to be cutted"
   - Ps [Planes]: "Planes used as cutters"
   - As [Angles]: "Angle of rotation"
   - R [Round]: "Round hinge if true, Shapt hinge if true"
   - H [AtHinge]: "Turn at hinge if true else turn at origin of plane"
   - O [Offset]: "Offset of hinge, shift the distancewhen turning at hinge"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance"
   - Pa [Angles]: "Angle precision, by default 5° [0.5°, ["

   OUTPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry cutted and rotated"

----------------------------------------

   - DM [Display Mode]: "Optional Display mode to set this viewport to."
   - CL [Camera Location]: "The optional camera location point. This will override a named view."
   - CT [Camera Target]: "The optional camera target point. This will override a named view."
   - CPr [Camera Projection]: "an optional boolean value for the camera projection. False for parallel, true for perspective."
   - CLL [Camera Lens Length]: "Optional lens length for the perspective camera"

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

----------------------------------------

   - []L [Layer]: "Layer"
   - []CS [Colour Source]: "Source of Color(Object, Layer, Parent or Material). Connect ValueList for color sources."
   - Oc [Object Colour]: "Object Colour"
   - []Ms [Material Source]: "Source of Material (Object, Layer, Parent). Connect ValueList for material sources."
   - []Mn [Material Name]: "Material Name"
   - []Lt [Linetype]: "Linetype"
   - Pc [Print Colour]: "Print Colour"
   - Pw [Print Width]: "Print Width"
   - []Pcs [Print Colour Source]: "Source of Print Color(Object, Layer, Parent or Material). Connect ValueList for color sources."

   OUTPUTS:

   - K [Keys]: "User attribute keys"
   - V [Values]: "User attribute values"
   - N [Name]: "Name"
   - L [Layer]: "Layer"
   - CS [Colour Source]: "Source of Color(Object, Layer, Parent or Material). Connect ValueList for color sources."
   - Dc [Display Colour]: "Display Colour"
   - Ms [Material Source]: "Source of Material (Object, Layer, Parent). Connect ValueList for material sources."
   - Mn [Material Name]: "Material Name"
   - Lt [Linetype]: "Linetype"
   - Pc [Print Colour]: "Print Colour"
   - Pw [Print Width]: "Print Width"
   - Pcs [Print Colour Source]: "Source of Print Color(Object, Layer, Parent or Material). Connect ValueList for color sources."

   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:

   - B [Curve]: "Second Curve for the Dubins path, Start point will be used as ending point, Start tangent will be used as Direction (like Blend Component)"
   - R1 [Radius]: "Radius at start"
   - R2 [Radius]: "Radius at End"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Shortest]: "Shortest path"
