----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to create twisted box array on"
   - T [Thickness]: "Overall thickness of the twisted box array, offset from the surface"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domain ({u}0.0 = Surface start, {u}1.0 = Surface end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domain ({v}0.0 = Surface start, {v}1.0 = Surface end)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface, {w}1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Deserialize
   (Tab: Pancake > Panel: 01 | Input)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Serialized]: "Serialized object"

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [Object]: "Object deserialized"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Vectors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Vector)

   INPUTS:
   - V [Vectors]: "Set of vectors to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Vector at V, 1.0 = Vector at V +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input vector set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween vectors"

----------------------------------------

## Extrude Unsplit Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Profile]: "Profile curve or surface to extrude"
   - D [Direction]: "Extrusion direction vector, curve, or point

Input a vector to exrude along a vector
Input a curve to exrude along a curve
Input a point to extrude to a point"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Unsplit]: "Resulting untrimmed single unsplit extruded surface

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component"

## Mesh Boolean Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twsisted boxes to trim"
   - M [Mesh]: "Closed mesh to trim with"
   - B [Boolean Type]: "True for boolean intersection (Trim away twisted boxes outside of the mesh)
False for boolean difference (Trim away twisted boxes inside of the mesh)"
   - K [Keep Type]: "Determines how much of the trimmed twisted box set to keep

0 = Complete (keep if twisted box is completely to the keep side of the mesh)
1 = Halfway (keep if twisted box is atleast halfway to the keep side of the mesh) (fastest)
2 = Partial (keep if twisted box is atleast partially to the keep side of the mesh)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Trimmed]: "Resulting trimmed twisted box set"
   - i [Kept Indicies]: "Indices from the input twisted box set of the twisted boxes that remained after the trimming"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mesh trimmed the twisted box set, False if the mesh did not trim the twisted box set"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: Curve > Panel: Spline)

   INPUTS:

   - B [Point B]: "End point of catenary"

   OUTPUTS:

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Planes On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl start, 1.0 = Plane at Pl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the curve between the plane extremes without considering the locations of the input plane set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on curve"

----------------------------------------

   - Source [Source]: "Material Source:
0) By Layer
1) By Object
3) By Parent"
   - Material [Material]: "Model Material"

----------------------------------------

## Rotate Plane Euler
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to rotate"
   - Pl [Plane]: "Intial base plane the rotation starts from"
   - A¹ [Axis 1]: "The first plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - A² [Axis 2]: "The second plane axis to rotate around, derived from the plane rotated around axis 1

0 = {x} of the plane rotated around axis 1
1 = {y} of the plane rotated around axis 1
2 = {z} of the plane rotated around axis 1"
   - A³ [Axis 3]: "The third plane axis to rotate around, derived from the plane rotated around axis 2

0 = {x} of the plane rotated around axis 2
1 = {y} of the plane rotated around axis 2
2 = {z} of the plane rotated around axis 2"
   - D¹ [Degrees 1]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 1 (α)"
   - D² [Degrees 2]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 2 (β)"
   - D³ [Degrees 3]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 3 (γ)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Rotated]: "Resulting rotated geometry"
   - Pl¹ [Plane 1]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 1 (axis 1 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - Pl² [Plane 2]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 2 (axis 2 is an axis from plane 1)"
   - Pl³ [Plane 3]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 3 (axis 3 is an axis from plane 2)"
   - X [Transform]: "Transformation data"

----------------------------------------

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"

## Twisted Box Strip Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - R¹ [Rail 1]: "Rail curve that the first and fifth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R² [Rail 2]: "Rail curve that the second and sixth corners of the twisted boxes are on"

   - t¹ [Parameters T1]: "Division parameters along rail curve one's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 1 start, 1.0 = Rail 1 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the parameters {t} t¹ list"
   - t² [Parameters T2]: "Division parameters along rail curve two's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 2 start, 1.0 = Rail 2 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the parameters {t} t² list"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input rail curves curvatures"

   OUTPUTS:

   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box curve around the twisted box centers at every {t} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box curve around the curve at every {t} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box curve is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

## Recursive Morph Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - B [Base Mesh]: "Base mesh to morph the first mesh geometry onto its faces
(best results if using a lower poly mesh and smoothing the result mesh)"
   - N [Steps]: "Number of recursive morphing steps

WARNING: Recursion creates new meshes on each mesh face potentially at an exponetial level. Step number values above 3 could create a lot of mesh faces. Please be sure to save your work in case your computer freezes with higher step numbers."
   - M [Meshes]: "A list of mesh geometries to morph, one mesh geometry for every recursive morphing step
(best results if using lower poly meshes and smoothing the result mesh)"
   - R [References]: "A list of reference boxes to morph from, one reference box for every recursive morphing step
(typically the bounding box of each mesh geometry to morph)"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses offset from mesh faces for morph heights, one thickness for every recursive morphing step"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld mesh vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother
(0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Morphed]: "Resulting recursive morphed mesh"

----------------------------------------

## Quantity Operator
   (Tab: Pancake > Panel: 03 | Quantity)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Operand A]: "First operand"
   - B [Operand B]: "Second operand"
   - O [Operator]: "Operator, which can be + or - or * or / or \ or % or max or min."

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Result]: "Result"

1 = Chord

3 = Uniform"

## Rotate Plane XYZ
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to rotate"
   - Pl [Plane]: "Intial base plane which defines the {x}, {y}, and {z} rotation axes"
   - A¹ [Axis 1]: "The first plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - A² [Axis 2]: "The second plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - A³ [Axis 3]: "The third plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - D¹ [Degrees 1]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 1"
   - D² [Degrees 2]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 2"
   - D³ [Degrees 3]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 3"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Rotated]: "Resulting rotated geometry"
   - Pl¹ [Plane 1]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 1 (axis 1 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - Pl² [Plane 2]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 2 (axis 2 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - Pl³ [Plane 3]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 3 (axis 3 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - X [Transform]: "Transformation data"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P start, 1.0 = Point at P end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input point set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input point set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point"

----------------------------------------

4) Decimal centimeters
5) Decimal meters
6) Decimal kilometers
7) Decimal inches
8) Decimal feet

   - Length Factor [Length Factor]: "Length factor"

   - Zero Suppression [Zero Suppression]: "Angle zero suppression: 
0) No zero suppression
1) Suppress leading zeros
2) Suppress trailing zeros

0) No stacking

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last mesh, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use normalized {w} division parameters ({w} 0.0 = Mesh at M start, {w} 1.0 = Mesh at M end)"

1 = Chord

   INPUTS:

   - U1 [U max]: "Upper limit of domain in {u} direction."
   - V0 [V min]: "Lower limit of domain in {v} direction."

## Twisted Box Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array through"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surface starts, {u}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surface starts, {v}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface at S start, {w}1.0 = Surface at S end), unless Normalized is False

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for {w} parameters are ({w}0.0 = Surface at index 0, {w}Index number of last surface = Surface at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last surface, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is evaluated along the interpolation path without considering the locations of the input surface set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Larger Than
   (Tab: Maths > Panel: Operators)

   INPUTS:
   - A [First Number]: "Number to test"
   - B [Second Number]: "Number to test against"

   OUTPUTS:
   - > [Larger than]: "True if A > B"
   - >= [… or Equal to]: "True if A >= B"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Surface Scattering
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Scatter)

   INPUTS:
   - Mode [Mode]: "Specifies the surface scattering mode. ‘Random Distribution’ scatters instances randomly on all Host mesh objects. ‘UV Grid’ uses UV mapping to scatter instances in regular patterns."
   - Instances Count [Instances Count]: "Determines the exact number of instances to scatter."
   - Per Area [Per Area]: "When enabled, the total number of instances is determined by the ‘Area Size’ value combined with the size of the host’s surface area."
   - Area Size [Area Size]: "The value specifies the length of the distribution square area side. If the ‘Instances Count’ value is set to 1, this number determines the relative density for all instances."
   - • Density Map [• Density Map]: "Determines the approximate count of instances based on texture input. Black color in the texture discards all instances in the respective area. Areas colored with white receive the maximum number of instances."
   - UV Channel [UV Channel]: "Determines the UV channel utilized for scattering."
   - Slope Limitation [Slope Limitation]: "Limits Scatter only to ‘slope’ at certain angles. The lower the angle range is set, the smaller the angle at which scattering stops. ‘Local’ - slope limitation is measured according to the Up vector of each individual Guest object. ‘World’ - slope limitation for all Guest objects is measured relative to the world Up vector."
   - Slope Angles [Slope Angles]: "The angle range in degrees outside which instances get filtered out."
   - Edge Trimming [Edge Trimming]: "Trims elements of instances outside of the host’s boundaries."
   - Grid Pattern [Grid Pattern]: "Determines the pattern when ‘UV Grid’ surface mode scattering is selected. ‘Grid’ - Rectangular grid. ‘Running Grid’ - Rectangular grid with every other row offset by half of the grid spacing. ‘Hexagonal Grid’ - Arranges instances into hexagons."
   - Grid Spacing [Grid Spacing]: "Scales the pattern in UV space based on vector input. When set to {1,1,0}, the pattern occupies the whole surface. When set to {0.5,0.5,0} it is repeated twice."
   - Grid Jitter [Grid Jitter]: "Determines what proportion of the instances are randomly placed along U and V axes based on vector input. When set to {0,0,0} all instances are placed according to UV mapping. When set to {1, 1, 0}, all instances are randomly placed."
   - Grid Offset [Grid Offset]: "Offsets the pattern by a given value along U and V axes based on vector input. Keep in mind that 0 and 1 Offset give the same result as 1 moves the pattern by 100% or one whole repetition."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Scattering [• Scattering Configuration]: "Configuration data specifying surface scattering mode. Can be connected to the V-Ray Scatter 2 component’s ‘Scattering Configuration’ input."

----------------------------------------

   - On [On]: "If true, Kangaroo will continue to iterate until reaching the given threshold value"

   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the vector set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"

To split the mirror combined vector set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."

## Twisted Box Pipe Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Pipe-like surface to create twisted boxes along the inside of"
   - u¹ [Parameters U1]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v1} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - u² [Parameters U2]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v2} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - u³ [Parameters U3]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v3} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - u⁴ [Parameters U4]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain at paramater {v4} (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {u} lists"
   - v¹ [Parameter V1]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the first and fifth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the lowest number of the {v} parameters"
   - v² [Parameter V2]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the second and sixth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v1} but a lower number than parameter {v3}"
   - v³ [Parameter V3]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the third and seventh corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v2} but a lower number than parameter {v4}"
   - v⁴ [Parameter V4]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the fourth and eigth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the largest number of the {v} parameters"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distributions are weighted by the input pipe-like surface curvature"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the twisted box flow if they are not flowing in the correct direction along the the inside of the pipe-like surface"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along the inside of the pipe-like surface"

----------------------------------------

## Slide Curve Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to slide along guide curve"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to slide along"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to slide along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Slide factor (0.0 = Slide start, 1.0 = Slide end)"
   - A [Align]: "Align the slide curve to the input curve, when using one guide curve"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped slides, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped slides, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Slid]: "Resulting curve slid along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Planes On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, numbers between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on curve"

----------------------------------------

## Evaluate Surface
   (Tab: Surface > Panel: Analysis)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Base surface"
   - uv [Point]: "{uv} coordinate to evaluate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Point]: "Point at {uv}"
   - N [Normal]: "Normal at {uv}"
   - U [U direction]: "U direction at {uv}"
   - V [V direction]: "V direction at {uv}"
   - F [Frame]: "Frame at {uv}"

----------------------------------------

## Soft & Hard Solver
   (Tab: Kangaroo2 > Panel: Main)

   INPUTS:
   - SoftGoals [SoftGoals]: "These goals will be met only if they do not conflict with the hard goals"
   - HardGoals [HardGoals]: "These goals will override the soft goals"
   - HardIterations [HardIterations]: "The number of hard iterations performed after each soft step"
   - SoftMultiplier [SoftMultiplier]: "Multiplier for the soft movement. This can be decreased to zero at the end if you want maximum accuracy"
   - Reset [Reset]: "Hard Reset (completely rebuild the particle list and indexing)"
   - Threshold [Threshold]: "Stop when average movement is less than this (default is 1e-15)"
   - Tolerance [Tolerance]: "Points closer than this distance will be combined into a single particle"
   - On [On]: "If true, Kangaroo will continue to iterate until reaching the given threshold value"

   OUTPUTS:
   - I [I]: "Iterations"
   - V [V]: "V"
   - O [O]: "GoalFunction Output tree"

----------------------------------------

## Orthocentre
   (Tab: Maths > Panel: Trig)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Point A]: "First triangle corner"
   - B [Point B]: "Second triangle corner"
   - C [Point C]: "Third triangle corner"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Orthocentre]: "Orthocentre point for triangle"
   - AB [Altitude AB]: "Altitude line connecting edge AB with corner C"
   - BC [Altitude BC]: "Altitude line connecting edge BC with corner A"
   - CA [Altitude CA]: "Altitude line connecting edge CA with corner B"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween between"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves"

----------------------------------------

## Render Point to Screen
   (Tab: Human > Panel: Display)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Point]: "Point to display to screen. Make sure the point is positioned at (or near) the world origin."
   - L [Location]: "The location to display the point. If "Scale With Viewport" is unchecked, specify points in pixel coordinates - 
 100,100,0 will be 100 pixels right and down from the upper-left corner of the viewport."
   - S [Scale Factor]: "A multiplier on the scale. Use this to adjust the size of the curve in the display."
   - C [Color]: "The color to display the point. "
   - R [Radius]: "The size to display the point. "
   - D [Depth]: "A value between 0-1 that controls the Z-depth of the point display. 
A high number will appear in front of most objects - low will go behind.
However, values exactly equal to 0 or 1 should be avoided - stay slightly within the 
limits to avoid artifacts"
   - F [Fixed]: "If true, objects remain fixed, oriented to the screen plane - if false, objects rotate when the viewport does."

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

## Tween Through Points On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, numbers between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Kangaroo Settings
   (Tab: Kangaroo > Panel: Kangaroo)

   INPUTS:
   - Tolerance [Tolerance]: "Input points less than this distance apart will be merged"
   - TimeStep [TimeStep]: "How far the system moves through time with each iteration. Smaller values increase stability at the cost of speed"
   - SubIterations [SubIterations]: "Number of timesteps per draw"
   - Floor [Floor]: "switches the floor plane on or off"
   - Drag [Drag]: "Viscous drag applied to all Nodes"
   - Restitution [Restitution]: "Coefficient of restitution between Nodes and Floor (ie Bounciness)"
   - StaticFriction [StaticFriction]: "Coefficient of static friction between Nodes and Floor"
   - KineticFriction [KineticFriction]: "Coefficient of kinetic friction between Nodes and Floor"
   - Settle [Settle]: "A cutoff speed for Nodes to stop bouncing"
   - Tumble [Tumble]: "A number between 0 and 1 affecting the retention of tangential velocity in floor collisions"
   - Sound [Sound]: "Switch sound effects on or off"
   - Solver [Solver]: "0= VelocityVerlet, 1= YoshidaSymplectic  , 2= Archimedes  , 3= ArchimedesRK4"

   OUTPUTS:
   - Settings [Settings]: "Global simulation settings"

----------------------------------------

   INPUTS:
   - L [Location]: "Location of text tag"
   - T [Text]: "The text to display"
   - C [Colour]: "Optional colour for tag"

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween through"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, numbers between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Domains²
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - I² [Domain²s]: "Set of domain²s to tween through"
   - uF [Factor U]: "Tween factor {u} (0.0 = Domain² {u} at start, 1.0 = Domain² {u} at end), unless Normalized is False"
   - vF [Factor V]: "Tween factor {v} (0.0 = Domain² {v} at start, 1.0 = Domain² {v} at end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Domain² {u}{v} at index 0, Index number of last domain² {u}{v} = Domain² {u}{v} at last index)

The tween factor range from one domain² {u}{v} to the next domain² {u}{v} in the list is:
Index number of a domain² {u}{v} = the domain² {u}{v} at that index, Index number of the next domain² {u}{v} = the next domain² {u}{v} in the list, factors between the domain² {u}{v} index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween domain² {u}{v} halfway between the domain² {u}{v} at index 2 and the domain² {u}{v} at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated between the extremes of the input domain² set without considering the locations of the input domain² set"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween domain²"

----------------------------------------

[!chars] (any single character not in chars)"

including 'Point,','Curve,''Brep,''Mesh,' 'Hatch,'
'Extrusion,' 'Light', 'Text,' and 'Block.' In addition,
'All' can be used to accept all types, and 'Default' will 
include only those types accepted by the built-in pipeline component."

The following wildcards are allowed:
? (any single character)
* (zero or more characters)

[chars] (any single character in chars)

   INPUTS:

   - Damping [Damping]: "Damping constant"
   - Rest length [Rest Length]: "The length the spring will try to reach"
   - Cutoff [Cutoff]: "If positive, springs only work below this distance; if negative only above this distance; and if 0 then they work at all distances"
   - CompFail [Compression Fail]: "Feature not yet operational"
   - TensFail [Tensile Fail]: "Feature not yet operational"
   - Plasticity [Plasticity]: "Maximum elastic deformation (as a factor of rest length). Deformations beyond this amount will alter the rest length of the spring. Set to zero for infinite (fully elastic, with no plasticity)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Springs]: "Springs Out"

   - Offset [Offset]: "Sets this lines 2D offset for line repetitions. Distance between each time the line you are defining repeats."
   - Segments [Segments]: "A list of segment lengths. Positive values are interpretted as a line. Negative values are interpretted as a gap."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Hatch Line [Hatch Line]: "The hatch pattern line."
   - Start [Start]: "The start point of the hatch line."
   - Direction [Direction]: "The tangent direction of the hatch line."
   - Shift [Shift]: "Sets this lines 2D shift for segment repetitions. Shift of pattern over from line to line."
   - Offset [Offset]: "Sets this lines 2D offset for line repetitions. Distance between each time the line you are defining repeats."
   - Segments [Segments]: "A list of segment lengths. Positive values are interpretted as a line. Negative values are interpretted as a gap."

## V-Ray Camera
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Render)

   INPUTS:
   - Type [Type]: "Switches the camera type.
Standard and VR cameras ignore Orthographic Zoom Factor parameter.
Orthographic cameras ignore FOV and Tilt parameters."
   - Stereo [Stereo]: "Enable Stereoscopic rendering mode.
The images for the left and right eyes will be rendered in "side by side" or in "top-bottom" layout"
   - Position [Position]: "Specifies the camera point position."
   - Target [Target]: "Specifies the camera target point position."
   - FOV [FOV]: "Camera field of view angle measured in degrees."
   - Tilt [Tilt]: "Tilts the camera around its aim vector.
The value is specified in degrees."
   - Ortho Zoom [Orthographic Zoom Factor]: "This parameter specifies the inverse of the orthographic scene width.
In orthographic mode the actual distance between the position and the target of the camera is meaningless and the field-of-view angle is set to 180 degrees. 
This parameter only works if the camera type is Orthographic."
   - Exposure On [Physical Exposure On]: "Enables the Physical Camera Exposure.
When enabled, the Exposure Value, F-Number, Shutter speed and ISO settings will affect the image brightness."
   - Wh. Balance [White Balance]: "Objects in the scene that have the specified color will appear white in the image.
Note that only the color hue is taken into consideration; the brightness of the color is ignored.
This parameter is ignored when Exposure is disabled."
   - F-Number [F-Number]: "The aperture (f-number) parameter determines the lens speed and consequently the brightness of the image.
Additionally, the f-number will affect the Depth of Field of the camera.
The smaller the f-number is, the more narrow the depth of field will be."
   - Shutter [Shutter Speed (1/s)]: "The shutter speed parameter determines the exposure time for the virtual camera.
The longer this time is (small shutter speed value), the brighter the image would be.
In reverse - if the exposure time is shorter (high Shutter speed value), the image would get darker."
   - ISO [Film Sensitivity]: "The film speed (ISO) parameter determines the sensitivity of the film and consequently the brightness of the image.
If the ISO value is high (film is more sensitive to the light), the image is brighter.
Lower ISO values mean that the film is less sensitive and produces a darker image."
   - Auto EV [Auto Exposure]: "Automatically determines an appropriate exposure value for the render.
Note that this option only works in the Production rendering mode."
   - Auto Wh. Balance [Auto White Balance]: "Automatically determines a suitable white balance value for the image.
Note that this option only works in the Production rendering mode.
When enabled, the camera's White Balance color is ignored."
   - DOF Focus [Depth of Field Focus]: "Setting this value to anything different than zero will enable depth of field (DOF).
The value also determines the focus distance."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Camera [• Camera]: "Camera output that can be connected to a V-Ray Render / Camera slot."
   - Angle [Angle]: "The XY angle to which the camera vector is rotated around the Z axis.
Can be connected to a Light Rig / Light Angle parameter to dynamically control the light position based on the camera location."
   - EV [Exposure Value]: "The exposure value based on the ISO, shutter speed and the F-number"

----------------------------------------

## Weaverbird's Sierpinski Triangles Subdivision
   (Tab: Wb > Panel: SubD)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh/Curves]: "The open or closed mesh, or closed curves list, to subdivide"
   - L [Level]: "The number of subdividing iterations for each face"

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [Output Mesh/Curves]: "The mesh after the subdividing process"

----------------------------------------

## Mesh Boolean Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twsisted boxes to trim"
   - M [Meshes]: "Closed mesh or meshes to trim with"
   - B [Boolean Type]: "True for boolean intersection (Trim away twisted boxes outside of the mesh or meshes)
False for boolean difference (Trim away twisted boxes inside of the mesh or meshes)"
   - K [Keep Type]: "Determines how much of the trimmed twisted box set to keep

0 = Complete (keep if twisted box is completely to the keep side of the mesh)
1 = Halfway (keep if twisted box is atleast halfway to the keep side of the mesh) (fastest)
2 = Partial (keep if twisted box is atleast partially to the keep side of the mesh)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Trimmed]: "Resulting trimmed twisted box set"
   - i [Kept Indicies]: "Indices from the input twisted box set of the twisted boxes that remained after the trimming"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the twisted box set was trimmed, False if the twisted box set was not trimmed"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Light Rig Sun System

## Beam
   (Tab: Kangaroo2 > Panel: Goals-6dof)

   INPUTS:
   - StartFrame [StartFrame]: "The plane at one end of the beam, its Z axis aligned with the beam direction"
   - EndFrame [EndFrame]: "Should be parallel to StartFrame"
   - StartNode [StartNode]: "The plane defining the node the start of the beam attaches to. If none supplied this defaults to XY aligned"
   - EndNode [EndNode]: "The plane defining the node the end of the beam attaches to. If none supplied this defaults to XY aligned"
   - E [E]: "Young's Modulus"
   - A [A]: "Cross-section area"
   - Ix [Ix]: "2nd moment of area about X"
   - Iy [Iy]: "2nd moment of area about Y"
   - GJ [GJ]: "Shear modulus * torsional constant"

   OUTPUTS:
   - B [Beam]: "B"

----------------------------------------

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"

## Medial Axis From Region
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - Cs [Curves]: "Planar curves"
   - A [Automatic]: "if automatic tolerance and distance will be choosen automatically"
   - Di [Distance]: "Distance between points on Curve to generate the Voronoi, limit of 20 000 points per curve"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance must be less tha Di/100, but in order to go fast not too low, choosen if automatic set to false"

   OUTPUTS:
   - Pl [Polyline]: "Polyline used, contour first then holes"
   - P [Plane]: "Plane for each region"
   - Ce [Voronoi Cells]: "Voronoi cells generated and cutted"
   - Ci [Circles]: "Circles inscribed"
   - Li [Lines]: "Lines linking the curve to the medial axis"
   - Ma [Medial Axis]: "Polylines representing Medial Axis"

   INPUTS:

A value of 1 will take the first available channel."
   - Repeat [Repeat]: "Determines how many times the texture will be repeated in the 0 to 1 UV square."
   - Offset [Offset]: "Controls the texture offset in the U and V direction."
   - Rotation [Rotation]: "Rotates the texture (in degrees)."
   - Tile [Tile]: "Specifies whether the texture will be tiled along the U and V axes respectively."
   - Mirror [Mirror]: "Specifies whether the texture will be mirror-wrapped along the U and V axes respectively."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • UVW [• UVW Placement]: "Texture placement in the object's UVW space"

   (Tab: Wb > Panel: SubD)

   INPUTS:

   - L [Level]: "The number of subdividing iterations for each face"
   - S [SmoothNakedEdges]: "When the value is true or not selected, the naked edges of any open mesh suppied will tend towards a spline. With false, naked edges will be kept coincident to the original ones"

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [OutputMesh]: "The mesh after the subdividing process"

## Weaverbird's Sierpinski Carpet
   (Tab: Wb > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh/Polylines]: "The mesh, or list of polylines, which will be processed."
   - D [Distance]: "The scalar value used in the construction of the new internal vertices.
Distance can be set as list, where each value applies to the correspondent element in the input mesh."
   - T [InsetType]: "Definition of distance for new vertices

0: Percent. Percentual of the length of the edge (must be < 50).
1: Parallelogram. Parallelogram rule (value < than shortest edge length / 2)."

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [OutMesh]: "The mesh after the process"

----------------------------------------

## Weaverbird's Mesh Window
   (Tab: Wb > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh/Polylines]: "The mesh, or list of polylines, which will be processed."
   - D [Distance]: "The scalar value used in the construction of the new internal vertices.
Distance can be set as list, where each value applies to the correspondent element in the input mesh."
   - T [InsetType]: "Definition of distance for new vertices

0: Percent. Percentual of the length of the edge (must be < 50).
1: Parallelogram. Parallelogram rule (value < than shortest edge length / 2)."

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [OutMesh]: "The mesh after the process"

----------------------------------------

## Weaverbird's Catmull-Clark Subdivision
   (Tab: Wb > Panel: SubD)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh/Curves]: "The open or closed mesh, or closed curves list, to subdivide"
   - L [Level]: "The number of subdividing iterations for each face"
   - S [Smooth Naked Edges]: "Defines how to treat the naked edges

0: Fixed. Naked edges will not move or be modified.
1: Smooth. The naked edge will tend toward a spline.
2: Corner Fixed. Corners (2-sided vertices) will be fixed, while other naked vertices will tend toward a spline.
"

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [Output Mesh/Curves]: "The mesh after the subdividing process"

----------------------------------------

## Model Linetype
   (Tab: Rhino > Panel: Drafting)

   INPUTS:
   - Model Linetype [Model Linetype]: "The Rhino model linetype"
   - Name [Name]: "The name of the linetype"
   - Segments [Segments]: "A list of segment lengths in millimeters. Positive values are interpretted as a line. Negative values are interpretted as a gap. If left empty or undefined, the linetype will be continuous."
   - Cap Style [Cap Style]: "Cap Style: 
0) Round
1) Flat
2) Square"
   - Join Style [Join Style]: "Join Style: 
0) Round
1) Miter
2) Bevel"
   - Width [Width]: "The linetype width when no taper points are defined"
   - Width Units [Width Units]: "The line width values will use these units to determine the size of the line on the screen."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Model Linetype [Model Linetype]: "The Rhino model linetype"
   - Name [Name]: "The name of the linetype"
   - Segments [Segments]: "A list of segment lengths in millimeters. Positive values are interpretted as a line. Negative values are interpretted as a gap. If the parameter is empty or undefined, the line will be continuous."
   - Cap Style [Cap Style]: "Cap Style: 
0) Round
1) Flat
2) Square"
   - Join Style [Join Style]: "Join Style: 
0) Round
1) Miter
2) Bevel"
   - Width [Width]: "The linetype width when no taper points are defined"
   - Width Units [Width Units]: "The line width values will use these units to determine the size of the line on the screen."

## Twisted Box Through Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to create twisted box array through"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through meshes {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Mesh at M start, {w}1.0 = Mesh at M end), unless Normalized is False

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for {w} parameters are ({w}0.0 = Mesh at index 0, {w}Index number of last mesh = Mesh at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last mesh, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is evaluated along the interpolation path without considering the locations of the input mesh set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through meshes"

----------------------------------------

   - type [Type Map]: "An index corresponding to the type of each object. 0 = point, 1 = curve, 2 = surface, 3 = brep, 4 = mesh, 5 = text, 6 = hatch, 7 = light, 8 = block, 9 = extrusion, 10 = other"

## Twisted Box Tube
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array around"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - D [Diameter]: "Outer diameter of the twisted box tube array"
   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the twisted box tube array, offset inward from the outer diameter corners"
   - O [Offset]: "Domain defined offset center location of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve
(0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotation 1]: "Rotation of the twisted box tube array around the diameter centers, in degrees"
   - R² [Rotation 2]: "Rotation of the twisted box tube array around the curve, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box tube array along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Parameter Rectangle Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - R [Rectangle]: "Rectangle to divide"
   - x [Parameters X]: "Division parameters along rectangle {x} domain (0.0 = {x}start, 1.0 = {x}end)

For best results {x} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - y [Parameters Y]: "Division parameters along rectangle {y} domain (0.0 = {y}start, 1.0 = {y}end)

For best results {y} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - T [Triangulate]: "Triangulate the mesh faces"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Resulting planar mesh from rectangle"

----------------------------------------

## Sub Curve
   (Tab: Curve > Panel: Spline)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Base curve]: "Base curve"
   - D [Domain]: "Sub-domain to extract"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Resulting sub curve"

----------------------------------------

## Seam
   (Tab: Curve > Panel: Util)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to adjust"
   - t [Seam]: "Parameter of new seam"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Adjusted curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curve on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last point = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, numbers between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Constrained Area Rectangle
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Plane]: "Base plane for rectangle"
   - A [Area]: "Area of the rectangle"
   - x [Factor X]: "Proportion factor in the plane {x} direction (use the same value for {x} and {y} for square)"
   - y [Factor Y]: "Proportion factor in the plane {y} direction (use the same value for {x} and {y} for square)"

   - Y [Dimension Y]: "Plane {y} dimension of the rectangle"

## Tween Through Domains
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - I [Domains]: "Set of domains to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Domain at I start, 1.0 = Domain at I end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Domain at index 0, Index number of last domain = Domain at last index)

The tween factor range from one domain to the next domain in the list is:
Index number of a domain = the domain at that index, Index number of the next domain = the next domain in the list, factors between the domain index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween domain halfway between the domain at index 2 and the domain at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated between the extremes of the input domain set without considering the locations of the input domain set"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween domain"

----------------------------------------

   - Position [Position]: "Light source location (point position).
If a list of input Positions is connected multiple lights will be generated.
Note: The number of input positions will determine the lights count."
   - Color [Color]: "Light source color."
   - Intensity [Intensity]: "Light source intensity. Calculated in the specified units."
   - Units [Intensity Units]: "Specifies the light unit of measurement.
Using correct units is essential when working with physical camera exposure.
The light will automatically take the scene units scale into consideration to produce the correct result for the scale being worked in."
   - Shadow Softness [Shadow Softness]: "Sets the shadow softness. Zero (0.0) makes the shadows perfectly sharp, larger values produce blurrier shadows."

## Twisted Box Sweep Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - R¹ [Rail 1]: "Rail curve that the first and fourth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R² [Rail 2]: "Rail curve that the second and third corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R³ [Rail 3]: "Rail curve that the sixth and seventh corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R⁴ [Rail 3]: "Rail curve that the fifth and eighth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - t¹ [Parameters T1]: "Division parameters along rail curve one's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 1 start, 1.0 = Rail 1 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {t} lists"
   - t² [Parameters T2]: "Division parameters along rail curve two's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 2 start, 1.0 = Rail 2 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {t} lists"
   - t³ [Parameters T3]: "Division parameters along rail curve three's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 3 start, 1.0 = Rail 3 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {t} lists"
   - t⁴ [Parameters T4]: "Division parameters along rail curve four's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 4 start, 1.0 = Rail 4 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the other parameter {t} lists"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distributions are weighted by the input rail curves curvatures"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting sweep twisted boxes"

----------------------------------------

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"

To split the mirror combined color set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."

## Tween Two Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Curve A]: "Curve along guide curve to tween from"
   - B [Curve B]: "Curve along guide curve to tween to"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from Curve A to Curve B)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve A, 1.0 = Curve B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Domains
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - I [Domains]: "Set of domains to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Domain at I, 1.0 = Domain at I +1)"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween domains"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Mesh at M, 1.0 = Mesh at M +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween meshes"

----------------------------------------

## Deconstruct Domain²
   (Tab: Maths > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - I [Domain]: "Base domain"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U0 [U min]: "Lower limit of domain in {u} direction"
   - U1 [U max]: "Upper limit of domain in {u} direction"
   - V0 [V min]: "Lower limit of domain in {v} direction"
   - V1 [V max]: "Upper limit of domain in {v} direction"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Pipe Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box pipe array around"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, the parameters {u} input is used as normalized lengths (0.5 = Curve middle).
If False, the parameters {u} input is used as curve parameters. (0.5 = Domain middle)."
   - D [Diameters]: "A list of outer diameters for the twisted box pipe array at every division parameter {u}"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses for the twisted box pipe array at every division parameter {u}, offset inward from the outer diameter corners"
   - R [Rotations]: "A list of rotations around curve for the twisted box pipe array at every division parameter {u}, in degrees"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array between"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surfaces start, {u}1.0 = Surfaces end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surfaces start, {v}1.0 = Surfaces end)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between each surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface at S start, {w}1.0 = Surface at S end)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Scatter 2
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Scatter)

   INPUTS:
   - • Hosts [• Hosts]: "Specifies the object(s), on which the instances will be scattered. Expects V-Ray Geometry (• V Geo) input."
   - • Guests [• Guests]: "Specifies the object(s) which will be scattered on the host object(s). Expects V-Ray Geometry (• V Geo) input."
   - Guest Origin [Guest Origin]: "Determines how objects will be positioned relative to the random Scatter points.
Bounding box bottom center - the bounding box bottom center of the object will match the Scatter point.
Bounding box volume center - the bounding box volume center will snap to the Scatter point.
Object origin - the original object origin point will snap to the Scatter point."
   - Guest Weights [Guest Weights]: "A list of factors determining the relative probability of each guest to appear."
   - • Scattering [• Scattering Configuration]: "Specifies the Scattering mode based on input from one of the V-Ray Scatter Configuration components. 1D - On Splines - Objects are scattered along splines. When a mesh is added to the guests list, the items are scattered along all mesh edges. On Surfaces - Objects are scattered on surfaces. It doesn't matter if the surface is horizontal, vertical or if it is part of a complex 3D object. 3D - in a Bounding Box - Objects are scattered inside the object's bounding box. Keep in mind that bounding boxes are cube-shaped, therefore using this mode on a round object scatters instances in a cube around it."
   - Max Count [Max Count (Limit)]: "Limits the maximum number of instances. Note that this option does not determine how many instances are created. Instead it serves as a measure to avoid scattering too many instances and causing a crash."
   - Seed [Seed]: "Controls the random seed of the Scatter.
Change this integer value and refresh to get a different random distribution."
   - Avoid Collisions [Avoid Collisions]: "If turned on, bounding boxes of instances that overlap any other instance bounding box will be skipped. Note that enabling this option may reduce the overall number of instances."
   - Collisions Threshold [Collisions Threshold]: "Controls the size of bounding boxes used to detect collisions. Smaller values result in denser scattering with some collisions and higher values result in larger distances between instances. Values above 1 mean that the distance between objects is larger than their bounding boxes."
   - Random Translation [Random Translation]: "Intervals of minimum and maximum factor for the random instance translation along X, Y and Z axes."
   - Translation Step [Translation Step]: "Determines a distinct distance between all instances. If the value is left at zero, instances are translated continuously."
   - Random Rotation [Random Rotation]: "Intervals of minimum and maximum factor for the random instance rotation along X, Y and Z axes."
   - Rotation Step [Rotation Step]: "Determines a fixed angle (in degrees) by which all instances are randomly rotated."
   - Normal Alignment [Normal Alignment]: "When a value different than 0 is entered, the instances are aligned according to the world Z axis. This is useful when the Host object is curved and the scattered objects need to remain vertical, not follow the curve of the surface. Positive values mean that the instances are aligned to the +Z axis (vertical up) and negative values mean that the instances are aligned to the -Z axis (vertical down)."
   - Random Scale [Random Scale]: "Intervals of minimum and maximum factor for the random instance scaling along X, Y and Z axes."
   - Scale Step [Scale Step]: "Determines a percentage of scaling to be applied to all instances. Otherwise, scaling is continuous."
   - • Area Modifiers [• Area Modifiers]: "Scatters Guest objects everywhere on the Host objects, except for or exclusively in the areas specified by a V-Ray Area Modifier component."
   - Cam Clip On [Camera Clipping On]: "Enables Camera Clipping."
   - Cam Clip Extend View [Camera Clipping Extend View]: "Specifies an extension to the camera view in all directions. All instances inside the Extend view are not clipped."
   - Cam Clip Distance [Camera Clipping Threashold]: "Determines the distance range from the camera, outside of which instances are clipped.
An empty domain will disable the distance clipping altogether."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • V Geo [• V Geometry]: "V-Ray Geometry output.
Can be connected to the V-Ray Render / Geometry slot."

----------------------------------------

## Shrink Trimmed Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Trimmed surface (or polysurface (Brep)) to shrink underlying untrimmed surface of"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Shrunken]: "Resulting trimmed surface (or polysurface (Brep)) with shrunken underlying untrimmed surface"
   - U [Underlying]: "The shrunken underlying untrimmed surface of the trimmed surface (or polysurface (Brep))"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if the trimmed surface's underlying untrimmed surface shrank
False if the trimmed surface's underlying untrimmed surface was already shrunk or the input surface was untrimmed"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Tube Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array around"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - D [Diameters]: "A list of outer diameters for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter, offset inward from the outer diameter corners"
   - O [Offsets]: "A list of domain defined offset center locations of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve at every {u} division parameter (0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the diameter centers at every {u} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the curve at every {u} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

----------------------------------------

   - Aspect [Aspect Ratio]: "Maximum aspect ratio of quads in the initial grid."

## V-Ray Light Rectangle
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Lighting)

   INPUTS:
   - On [On]: "Enables or disables the light source."
   - Plane [Base plane]: "The Rectangle light base plane, where its geometry is positioned and orientated along."
   - Color [Color]: "Light source color."
   - Intensity [Intensity]: "Light source intensity. Calculated in the specified units."
   - Units [Intensity Units]: "Specifies the light unit of measurement.
Using correct units is essential when working with physical camera exposure.
The light will automatically take the scene units scale into consideration to produce the correct result for the scale being worked in."
   - Invisible [Invisible]: "Controls the Light source visibility. Does not affect its illuminance."
   - Shape [Shape]: "Specifies the shape of the light object."
   - U Size [U Size]: "Determines the U size of the light (half-width of the rectangle) measured in scene units."
   - V Size [V Size]: "Determines the V size of the light (half-height of the rectangle) measured in scene units."
   - Dir [Directionality]: "Specifies the spread of the light beam. Value of 0 will emit light equally in all directions. Increasing the value makes the light beam more narrow and concentrates it in one direction"

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Light [• Add Light]: "Light output that can be connected to a Renderer"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Combine Items
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: List)

   INPUTS:
   - L [Items]: "Set of list items to mirror combine"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (False = End of set, True = Start of set)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror combined list item set (removes the duplicate item in the middle of the set)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirrored]: "Resulting mirror combined list item set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirrored combined list item set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, numbers between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Domains²
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - I² [Domain²s]: "Set of domain²s to mirror cut"
   - Mi [Mirror Index]: "Index that the kept side of the domain² set cut gets mirrored across.
Negative index reverses the domain² set and removes from the top."
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (False = Mirror after index, True = Mirror before index)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut domain² set (removes the duplicate domain² in the middle of the set)"
   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the domain² set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut domain² set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut domain² set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mirror index intersected the domain² set, False if the mirror index did not intersect the domain² set"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Points On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on curve to tween between"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween points on"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Planes On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Plane at Pl start, Factor 1.0 = Plane at Pl end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on surface"

----------------------------------------

   - S± [Secondary (error)]: "Errors on Secondary moments"
   - G [Gyration]: "Radii of gyration"
