## Curve Align Curve Seams
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of closed curves to align seams of"
   - G [Guide]: "Guide curve to align the seams along"
   - S [Snap]: "If curve has corners, snap the aligned seam to the closest corner or kink"

   OUTPUTS:
   - A [Aligned]: "Resulting curves with aligned seams"
   - P [Points]: "Points at the aligned curve seams"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if curve is closed with an aligned seam, False if curve is opened"

----------------------------------------

## Fillet Edge
   (Tab: Surface > Panel: Util)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Shape]: "Shape to fillet"
   - B [Blend]: "Fillet blend type"
   - M [Metric]: "Fillet metric type"
   - E [Edges]: "Edge indices to fillet"
   - R [Radii]: "Fillet radii/measures per edge"

   OUTPUTS:
   - B [Result]: "Filleted Brep"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Polysurface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - Ps [Polysurface]: "Polysurface(Brep) or surface to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the polysurface(Brep) or surface cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the polysurface(Brep) or surface within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the polysurface(Brep) or surface from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut polysurface(Brep) or surface"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the polysurface(Brep) or surface and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut polysurfaces(Breps) or surfaces are connected

0 = Straight
1 = Uniform
2 = Loose
3 = Tight
4 = None"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut polysurface(Brep) or surface connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut polysurfaces(Breps) or surfaces"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut polysurface(Brep) or surface set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the polysurface(Brep) or surface was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the polysurface(Brep) or surface was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at S, 1.0 = Surface at S +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surfaces"

----------------------------------------

   INPUTS:

   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl, 1.0 = Plane at Pl +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input plane set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween planes"

----------------------------------------

## Populate an Image
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Populate)

   INPUTS:
   - Image [I]: "Location/Path of image file (BMP, GIF, EXIF, JPG, PNG and TIFF), or Image, or Mesh (from image)"
   - nRb [nRadiusBlack]: "Normalized radius for the black, if 1 it equals the width of the image [1e-4, 1]"
   - nRw [nRadiusWhite]: "Normalized radius for the white, if 1 it equals the width of the image [1e-4, 1]"
   - mC [MaxContrast]: "If true maximalise the contrast"
   - D [Division]: "Circles overpopulation factor [1, 20]"
   - S [SortCircles]: "Sort the list of overlapping circles, 0 no change in the list, -1 sort radius descending,  1 sort radius ascending, , 2 sort X of the center ascending, 3 sort Y of the center ascending"
   - Max [Max]: "Maximum number of points per pixel"
   - S [Seed]: "Seed for the random "

   OUTPUTS:
   - I [Image]: "Image as mesh"
   - C [Circles]: "Circles"
   - Cs [CirclesSorted]: "Circles"
   - Rb [Radius B]: "Radius for the black in real size"
   - Rw [Radius W]: "Radius for the white in real radius"

----------------------------------------

## MultiPipe
   (Tab: Surface > Panel: SubD)

   INPUTS:
   - Curves [Curves]: "The curves to pipe. Also accepts meshes"
   - NodeSize [NodeSize]: "Pipe radius. If one value given, it is applied to all. Alternatively, provide a list of radii corresponding to each point in SizePoints"
   - SizePoints [SizePoints]: "If you are supplying multiple radii for NodeSize, these points identify which node to set as which radius. If only some of the nodes have their radius set this way, the values will be interpolated across the shape"
   - EndOffset [EndOffset]: "The distance of the first edge loop away from the node as a multiplier of NodeSize. If this is set to zero, no intermediate edge loop is added, to give a smoother shape."
   - StrutSize [StrutSize]: "The size of the struts between nodes as a multiplier of NodeSize. <1 gives tapering struts, >1 gives bulging struts"
   - Segment [Segment]: "Approximate spacing of edge loops along each strut. If set to zero, no additional edge loops are added"
   - KinkAngle [KinkAngle]: "When the input to 'Curves' are smooth curves, this sets the maximum angle between consecutive segments when discretizing"
   - CubeFit [CubeFit]: "If >0 this attempts to fit a cube at each node. Should be a value between 0 and 1, where 0 = never, and 1 = always, depending on how close to orthogonal its connected lines are."
   - Caps [Caps]: "Cap option - 0:None, 1:Round, 2:Flat"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Pipe]: "Resulting Pipe SubD"

----------------------------------------

0: Fixed. Naked edges will not move or be modified.
1: Smooth. The naked edge will tend toward a spline.
2: Corner Fixed. Corners (2-sided vertices) will be fixed, while other naked vertices will tend toward a spline.
"
   - T [Thin]: "The final, one-shot, thinning with the original mesh"

Higher numbers will appear in front of most objects - lower will go behind.
However, values that are too high may cause the display to disappear completely."

## Light GBM Binary Classifier
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Trainer Types)

   INPUTS:
   - Leaves [Number of Leaves]: "The max number of leaves in each tree."
   - Iterations [Number of Iterations]: "The number of boosting iterations. A new tree is created in each iteration, so this is equivalent to the number of trees."
   - Count [Minimum Example Count Per Leaf]: "The minimal number of data points required to form a new tree leaf."
   - Learning [Learning Rate]: "The shrinkage rate for trees, used to prevent over-fitting."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Trainer Type [Trainer Type]: "The trainer used for machine learning problems."

----------------------------------------

## Spiral From Polyline
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Spiral)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Polyline]: "Closed and Convex Polyline, if it is a closed curve tolerance will be used to convert curve to polyline"
   - D [Distance]: "Min distance between spiral arm"
   - N [nTurns]: "Number of turns > 0"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance for "

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Spiral]: "Spiral as a polyline"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted boxes along"
   - t [Parameters T]: "Division parameters along curve {t} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - X [Size X]: "Domain size of the twisted box curve {x} dimension"
   - Y [Size Y]: "Domain size of the twisted box curve {y} dimension"
   - R¹ [Rotation 1]: "Rotation of the twisted box curve around the twisted box centers, in degrees"
   - R² [Rotation 2]: "Rotation of the twisted box curve around the curve, in degrees
(if the twisted box curve is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along curve"

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input curve set"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve"

----------------------------------------

## Transform
   (Tab: Kangaroo2 > Panel: Goals-Pt)

   - P0 [P0]: "First Point"
   - P1 [P1]: "Second Point"
   - T [T]: "Transformation from P0 to P1"
   - Strength [Strength]: "Strength"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Transform]: "Transform out"

----------------------------------------

## MeshMachine
   (Tab: Kangaroo > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - Geom [Geometry]: "Input Surface or Mesh"
   - Length [Length]: "Target edge length"
   - FixC [FixCurves]: "Curves which will be kept sharp during remeshing. Can be boundary or internal curves"
   - FixV [FixVertices]: "Points to keep fixed during remeshing"
   - Flip [Flip]: "Criterion used to decide when to flip edges (0 for valence based, 1 for angle based)"
   - Pull [PullStrength]: "Strength of pull to target geometry (between 0 and 1). Set to 0 for minimal surfaces"
   - Adapt [CurvatureAdaptivity]: "If greater than 0, edges will be shorter in regions of tighter curvature (Values between 0 and 1 blend between uniform lengths and fully curvature dependent)"
   - BScale [BoundaryScale]: "Edge length reduction factor at boundaries. Should be greater than 0 and less than 1"
   - BDist [BoundaryDistance]: "Distance over which to blend to boundary edge scale"
   - SizP [SizePoints]: "Locations for edge length values to interpolate between"
   - SizV [SizeValues]: "Edge lengths to interpolate"
   - Exp [Exponent]: "Power for interpolation (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_distance_weighting#Shepard.27s_method)"
   - Bkgd [Background]: "Weighting for background edge length in interpolation"
   - Iter [Iterations]: "Number of steps between outputs"
   - Reset [Reset]: "True to initialize, false to run remeshing. Connect a timer for continuous remeshing"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Remeshed result as Plankton Mesh"

----------------------------------------

## Unsplit Loft Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Sections]: "Set of section curves or surfaces to loft through"
   - C [Closed]: "Closed loft, if true the last section curve will loft back to the first section curve"
   - T [Loft Type]: "Determines how the section curves are lofted

0 = Normal
1 = Loose
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform
4 = Straight"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Unsplit]: "Resulting untrimmed single unsplit lofted surface

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component."

## Surface Trim Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twsisted boxes to trim"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to trim with"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the trim direction"
   - K [Keep Type]: "Determines how much of the trimmed twisted box set to keep

0 = Complete (keep if twisted box is completely to the keep side of the surface)
1 = Halfway (keep if twisted box is atleast halfway to the keep side of the surface) (fastest)
2 = Partial (keep if twisted box is atleast partially to the keep side of the surface)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Trimmed]: "Resulting trimmed twisted box set"
   - i [Kept Indicies]: "Indices from the input twisted box set of the twisted boxes that remained after the trimming"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the surface trimmed the twisted box set, False if the surface did not trim the twisted box set"

## Möbius Transformation
   (Tab: Kangaroo2 > Panel: Utility)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Input Geometry to transform"
   - C [Circle]: "Circle defining the transformation. Points on this circle will stay on it, and all other points are pulled through and around it"
   - T [T]: "Amount of transformation. 2π brings it back to the original"
   - Q [Q]: "This parameter controls the rotation around the axis of the circle. Set to 1 for Isoclinic rotations"
   - F [FixSphere]: "If true, this transforms and scales the geometry so that points on the sphere defined by the input circle stay on that sphere"

   OUTPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Transformed Geometry"

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between surfaces {w} domain (0.0 = Surface A, 1.0 = Surface B)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"

   OUTPUTS:

If the value is false, the baked object would maintain its original attribute no matter what is defined by baking plugin, e.g. Elefront, Human.

## Tween Consecutive Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween between"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves along curve"

## Tween Through Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twisted boxes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Twisted Box at TB start, 1.0 = Twisted Box at TB end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Twisted Box at index 0, Index number of last twisted box = Twisted Box at last index)

The tween factor range from one twisted box to the next twisted box in the list is:
Index number of a twisted box = the twisted box at that index, Index number of the next twisted box = the next twisted box in the list, factors between the twisted box index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween twisted box halfway between the twisted box at index 2 and the twisted box at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input twisted box set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input twisted box set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween twisted box"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the mesh cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the mesh within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the mesh from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut mesh"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the mesh and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut meshes are connected

0 = Split faces, with connection
1 = Remove faces, with connection
2 = Shrink faces, with connection
3 = Split faces, without connection
4 = Remove faces, without connection
5 = Shrink faces, without connection"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut mesh connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"
   - D [Divisions]: "Number of mesh faces per side of the mesh connection"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld mesh vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother
(0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut meshes"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut mesh set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mesh was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the mesh was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Point at P start, Factor 1.0 = Point at P end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: Rhino > Panel: Content)

   INPUTS:

   - Value [Value]: "The value to compare"

   OUTPUTS:
   - Greater Than [Greater Than]: "A filter that determines if a value is greater than another"
   - … or Equal [… or Equal]: "A filter that determines if a value is greater than or equal to another"

   - Name [Name]: "A name pattern used to filter results.
Right-click on this parameter to set the matching method."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Directory [Directory]: "The absolute file system directory path"
   - Directories [Directories]: "The resultant list of available subdirectories"
   - Files [Files]: "The resultant list of available files"

   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut mesh"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the mesh and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut meshes are connected

0 = Split faces, with connection
1 = Remove faces, with connection
2 = Shrink faces, with connection
3 = Split faces, without connection
4 = Remove faces, without connection
5 = Shrink faces, without connection"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut mesh connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"

## V-Ray Infinite Plane
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Geometry)

   INPUTS:
   - Geo [Geo]: "Geometries input expected.
By default the Infinite Plane will be placed at the scene origin.
When an object or group of objects is connected here the plane will be automatically placed underneath the objects bounding-box as long as the ‘From Geo’ (Position from Geometry) input is set to True."
   - • Mtl [• Mtl]: "V-Ray Material input expected."
   - Sh. Catch On [Shadow Catcher On]: "V-Ray Material input expected."
   - Z Offset [Z Offset]: "Offsets the position of the Infinite Plane along the Z axis.
Negative values can also be used here.
Note: While a Geometry input is present the Z offset value will be ignored."
   - From Geo [Position From Geometry]: "Calculates the Z position as the lowest most point of the plugged in geometry"

   OUTPUTS:
   - • V Geo [• V Geometry]: "V-Ray Geometry output.
Can be connected to the V-Ray Render / Geometry slot."

----------------------------------------

## Single Line Fill with Hexagons
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Print)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "List of curves, planar and non intersecting, add line in the same plane if you want to align the pattern with the line "
   - S [Hexagon Size]: "Hexagon size"
   - A [Hexagon Angle]: "Hexagon Angle (°)"
   - W [Print Width]: "Print Width or Offset Distance or Distance between Patterns"
   - B [Relative Bridge Width]: "Bridge Width Factor relative to Print Width"
   - Bo [Use Border Curves]: "If true use the border curves"
   - G [Guide Curve]: "Guide curve used to position the hexagons, by default a line oriented on Z "
   - S [Relative Search Distance]: "Search factor relative to Print Width"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance used to convert the curves to polyline"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Polylines]: "Polylines sorted used as borders, first polyline is the outside, others are the holes"
   - Pl [Planes]: "Planes"
   - Pa [Patterns Closed]: "Closed curves patterns"
   - Po [Patterns Opened]: "Opened curves patterns"
   - B [Bridges]: "Bridges"
   - S [Single Line Fill]: "Single line fill, if OK just one polyline"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Consecutive Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to create twisted box array between"
   - T [Thickness]: "Overall thickness of the twisted box array, offset from the curves"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters between each curves {u} domain ({u}0.0 = Curve at C, {u}1.0 = Curve at C +1)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along curve {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Curve starts, {v}1.0 = Curve ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Curves, {w}1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {v} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvatures"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {u} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between curves"

----------------------------------------

## Pinch'n'Spread Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to pinch & spread"
   - L [Locations]: "Set of points that define the locations to pinch & spread at"
   - R [Radii]: "Set of radii that determine how far the pinch & spread reaches from the location points, one radius for each location point"
   - S [Strengths]: "Set of strengths that determine how much to pinch & spread within each radius, one strength for each radius

Pinch (0.0 = Weakest, 1.0 = Strongest)
Spread (0.0 = Weakest, -1.0 = Strongest)"
   - F [Falloffs]: "Set of falloffs that determine how the strengths pull gradually falls off, one falloff for each strength

Falloff (0.0 = Sharpest, 1.0 = Smoothest)"
   - E [Exponents]: "Set of exponents that determine the exponential pulling power of the falloffs, one exponent for each falloff"
   - W¹ [Weights 1]: "Set of weights that pulls the falloffs smoothly towards the pinch & spread direction, one weight 1 for each falloff

Weight 1 (0.0 = Lightest, 1.0 = Heaviest)"
   - W² [Weights 2]: "Set of weights that pulls the falloffs sharply towards the pinch & spread direction, one weight 2 for each falloff

Weight 2 (0.0 = Lightest, 1.0 = Heaviest)"
   - A [Anchors]: "Optional anchor points from the set of points to pinch & spread which will not be moved by the pinch & spread"

   OUTPUTS:
   - PS [Pinched & Spread]: "Resulting pinched & spread points"

----------------------------------------

## Blend Consecutive Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to blend between"
   - F [Factors]: "Blend factors, one factor for each set of vertices which share the same vertex index from mesh to mesh
(0.0 = Mesh at M vertices, 1.0 = Mesh at M +1 vertices)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, blend distribution is weighted by the input mesh sets vertices and the vertex blend paths curvatures"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the blend path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the vertex blend paths, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the vertex blend paths are interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - C [Colored Type]: "Determines how mesh vertex colors are blended

0 = None
1 = Fast
2 = Accurate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - B [Blend]: "Resulting blend meshes"

----------------------------------------

## Polysurface Boolean Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twsisted boxes to trim"
   - Ps [Polysurface]: "Closed polysurface(Brep) to trim with"
   - B [Boolean Type]: "True for boolean intersection (Trim away twisted boxes outside of the polysurface(Brep))
False for boolean difference (Trim away twisted boxes inside of the polysurface(Brep))"
   - K [Keep Type]: "Determines how much of the trimmed twisted box set to keep

0 = Complete (keep if twisted box is completely to the keep side of the polysurface(Brep))
1 = Halfway (keep if twisted box is atleast halfway to the keep side of the polysurface(Brep)) (fastest)
2 = Partial (keep if twisted box is atleast partially to the keep side of the polysurface(Brep))"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Trimmed]: "Resulting trimmed twisted box set"
   - i [Kept Indicies]: "Indices from the input twisted box set of the twisted boxes that remained after the trimming"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the polysurface(Brep) trimmed the twisted box set, False if the polysurface(Brep) did not trim the twisted box set"

----------------------------------------

## To Feet & Inch Length
   (Tab: Pancake > Panel: 03 | Quantity)

   INPUTS:
   - Q [Quantity]: "Quantity to be converted.
If the input is not an quantity but a number, the document modelling unit will be used."
   - P [Precision]: "Precision.
For decimal quantities, the precision is how many digits are preserved after the decimal point.
For feet and inch length, the precision is the minimal fraction to be preserved. e.g. Precision = 64 will yield 1 / 64 as the smallest stepping. Precision doesn't need to be a power of two."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Q [Quantity]: "Output quantity"

## LineLine
   (Tab: Kangaroo > Panel: Forces)

   INPUTS:
   - L1Start [L1Start]: "Start point of the first line"
   - L1End [L1End]: "End point of the first line"
   - L2Start [L2Start]: "Start point of the second line"
   - L2End [L2End]: "End point of the second line"
   - Strength [Strength]: "Strength of Line-Line interaction force"
   - UpperCutoff [UpperCutoff]: "Interaction only activates BELOW this distance. Set to 0 for no limit"
   - LowerCutoff [LowerCutoff]: "Interaction only activates ABOVE this distance"
   - Offset [Offset]: "Rest distance between the 2 line segments (If colliding cylinders then the sum of their radii)"
   - Exponent [Exponent]: "Power to raise the distance to (1 for springs)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - LineLine [LineLine]: "LineLine out"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Array
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - B [Box]: "Box to create twisted box array in"
   - x [Parameters X]: "Division parameters along the box {x} domain (0.0 = {x}start, 1.0 = {x}end)

For best results {x} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - y [Parameters Y]: "Division parameters along the box {y} domain (0.0 = {y}start, 1.0 = {y}end)

For best results {y} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - z [Parameters Z]: "Division parameters along the box {z} domain (0.0 = {z}start, 1.0 = {z}end)

For best results {z} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the surface cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the surface within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the surface from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut surfaces"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the surface and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut surfaces are connected

0 = Linear
1 = Tangency
2 = Curvature
3 = None"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut surface connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut surfaces"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut surface set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the surface was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the surface was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Tube
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:

   - R [Radius]: "Outer radius of the twisted box tube array"
   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the twisted box tube array, offset inward from the outer radius corners"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Radius, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - O [Offset]: "Domain defined offset center location of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve
(0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotation 1]: "Rotation of the twisted box tube array around the radius centers, in degrees"
   - R² [Rotation 2]: "Rotation of the twisted box tube array around the curve, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box tube array along curve"

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh"
   - N [Noise Type]: "Cellular=0, OpenSimplex2=1, OpenSimplex2S=2, Perlin=3, Value=4,ValueCubic=5"

   - F [Frequency]: "The cell size (real unit) is 1 / Frequency"
   - R [Fractal Type]: "FractalType.None = 0, , FractalType.FBm = 1, FractalType.PingPong = 2, FractalType.Ridged = 3"
   - O [Octaves]: "Number of octaves (1,12)"
   - L [Lacunarity]: "Lacunarity"
   - G [Gain]: "Gain [0, 1]"
   - W [FractalWeightedStrength]: "FractalWeightedStrength [0, 1]"
   - P [PingPong Strength]: "Gain [0, 10["
   - D [Distance Type]: "Euclidean   = 0, EuclideanSq = 1,Hybrid = 2,Manhattan = 3"
   - C [CellularReturnType]: "CellValue    = 0, Distance = 1, Distance2 = 2, Distance2Add = 3, Distance2Div = 4,Distance2Mul = 5, Distance2Su = 6"
   - J [cellularJitter]: "Jitter for [0, 1]"
   - I [Invert]: "Invert"
   - Gr [Gradient]: "Connect a Gradient to control the output coloring"
   - S [Seed]: "Random seed"
   - DW [Warp Domain Type]: "None   = 0, OpenSimplex2 = 1,OpenSimplex2Reduced = 2,BasicGrid = 3"
   - Rw [Warp Rotation 3d]: "None = 0, ImproveXYPlanes = 1, ImproveXZPlanes = 2"
   - Aw [Warp  Amplitude]: "Maximum movement distance"
   - Sw [Warp  Seed]: "Random seed"
   - Fw [Warp Frequency]: "The cell size (real unit) is 1 / Frequency"
   - R [Fractal Type]: "FractalType.None = 0, FractalType.DomainWarpIndependent =1, FractalType.DomainWarpProgressive = 2"
   - Ow [Warp Octaves]: "Number of octaves (1,12)"
   - Lw [Warp Lacunarity]: "Lacunarity"
   - Gw [Warp Gain]: "Gain [0, 1]"

   OUTPUTS:

   - Wv [Output Noise]: "Weight for each mesh Vertex, [-1, 1] or [0, 1]"

## Tween Two Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Curve A]: "Curve along guide curve to tween from"
   - B [Curve B]: "Curve along guide curve to tween to"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from Curve A to Curve B)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve A, 1.0 = Curve B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

The light will automatically take the scene units scale into consideration to produce the correct result for the scale being worked in."
   - Rotation [Rotation]: "Horizontally rotates the Dome Light."

## Recursive Transform
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to recursively transform"
   - X [Transform]: "Transformation that will be used to transform the geometry at each recursive step
(X outputs of components that perform transformations like Move, Scale, Rotate, etc.)

Use Pufferfish's Mass Transform component or Grasshopper's Compound component to combine multiple transformations into one transform to use in this input, so multiple transformations can affect the geometry.

(*Be extra careful with transformations such as scaling as recursively scaling with many steps can quickly generate extremely large or small sized geometry, which may freeze Grasshopper)"
   - N [Steps]: "Number of recursive transformation steps"
   - L [Last]: "If True, only the last step of the recursive transform is calculated and output.
If False, every step of the recursive transform is calculated and output."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Transformed]: "Resulting recursively transformed geometry"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Colors]: "Set of colors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Color at index 0, Index number of last color = Color at last index)

The tween factor range from one color to the next color in the list is:
Index number of a color = the color at that index, Index number of the next color = the next color in the list, numbers between the color index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween color halfway between the color at index 2 and the color at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - a [Alpha]: "Tween the transparencies (alpha values) of the colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween color"

----------------------------------------

## Shear
   (Tab: Transform > Panel: Affine)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Base geometry"
   - P [Base]: "Base plane"
   - G [Grip]: "Reference point"
   - T [Target]: "Target point"

## V-Ray Instancer
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Geometry)

   INPUTS:

Multiple geometries can be used here.
V-Ray will randomly distribute the inputs between the Move positions."
   - Move [Move Transformation]: "List of Move (position) transformations used for instance positioning.
Usually the Transformation (X) output of a Move component is used here.
The number of input transformations will determine the number of instances."
   - Rotate [Rotate Transformation]: "List of Rotate transformations used for instance orientation.
Usually the Transformation (X) output of a Rotate 3D / Rotate / ... component is used here."
   - Scale [Scale Transformation]: "List of Scale transformations used for instance scaling.
Usually the Transformation (X) output of a Scale / Scale NU component is used here."
   - Group [Group Objects]: "When enabled, all input objects will be treated as a group that is instanced at each point.
When disabled, input objects will be treated as separate items. A single object will be positioned at each point."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • V Geo [• V Geometry]: "V-Ray Geometry output."

## Twisted Box Pipe
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Pipe-like surface to create twisted boxes along the inside of"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v¹ [Parameter V1]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the first and fifth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the lowest number of the {v} parameters"
   - v² [Parameter V2]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the second and sixth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v1} but a lower number than parameter {v3}"
   - v³ [Parameter V3]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the third and seventh corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v2} but a lower number than parameter {v4}"
   - v⁴ [Parameter V4]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the fourth and eigth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the largest number of the {v} parameters"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input pipe-like surface curvature"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the twisted box flow if they are not flowing in the correct direction along the the inside of the pipe-like surface"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along the inside of the pipe-like surface"

----------------------------------------

 100,100,0 will be 100 pixels right and down from the upper-left corner of the viewport."

   - C [Color]: "The color to display the mesh. This will not override per-vertex mesh colors."
   - D [Depth]: "A value between 0-1 that controls the Z-depth of the mesh display. 
A high number will appear in front of most objects - low will go behind.
However, values exactly equal to 0 or 1 should be avoided - stay slightly within the 
limits to avoid artifacts"
   - F [Fixed]: "If true, objects remain fixed, oriented to the screen plane - if false, objects rotate when the viewport does."

## V-Ray Exposure Value
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Render)

   INPUTS:
   - ISO [Film Sensitivity]: "The film speed (ISO) parameter determines the sensitivity of the film and consequently the brightness of the image.
If the ISO value is high (film is more sensitive to the light), the image is brighter.
Lower ISO values mean that the film is less sensitive and produces a darker image."
   - F [F-Number]: "The aperture (f-number) parameter determines the lens speed and consequently the brightness of the image.
Additionally, the f-number will affect the Depth of Field of the camera.
The smaller the f-number is, the more narrow the depth of field will be."
   - SS [Shutter Speed (1/s)]: "The shutter speed parameter determines the exposure time for the virtual camera.
The longer this time is (small shutter speed value), the brighter the image would be.
In reverse - if the exposure time is shorter (high Shutter speed value), the image would get darker."

   OUTPUTS:
   - EV [Exposure Value]: "The exposure value based on the ISO, shutter speed and the F-number"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:

   - S [Shader]: "A Grasshopper shader that approximates the render material as closely as possible."
   - Kd [Diffuse]: "Color of the diffuse channel"
   - Ks [Specular]: "Color of the specular highlight"
   - Ke [Emission]: "Emissive color of the material"

## Tween Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at S start, 1.0 = Surface at S end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Surface at index 0, Index number of last surface = Surface at last index)

The tween factor range from one surface to the next surface in the list is:
Index number of a surface = the surface at that index, Index number of the next surface = the next surface in the list, factors between the surface index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween surface halfway between the surface at index 2 and the surface at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input surface set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surface"

----------------------------------------

## Reparameterize Numbers
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Number)

   INPUTS:
   - N [Numbers]: "Set of numbers to reparameterize"
   - I [Invert]: "Invert the domain range to be from 1 to 0 instead of 0 to 1"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Reparameterized]: "Resulting reparameterized set of numbers"
   - O [Original]: "The original domain range of the set of numbers"

----------------------------------------

## Grid Structure

## Tween Through Vectors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Vector)

   INPUTS:
   - V [Vectors]: "Set of vectors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Vector at index 0, Index number of last vector = Vector at last index)

The tween factor range from one vector to the next vector in the list is:
Index number of a vector = the vector at that index, Index number of the next vector = the next vector in the list, numbers between the vector index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween vector halfway between the vector at index 2 and the vector at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween vector"

----------------------------------------

## Rebuild Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to rebuild"
   - R [Rebuild Normals]: "Recompute the mesh vertex and face normals"
   - C [Cull Unused]: "Remove unused vertices and faces from the mesh"
   - U [Unify Normals]: "Fix inconsistencies in the mesh vertex and face normals"
   - F [Flip Normals]: "Reverse the mesh vertex and face normals"
   - I [Identical Combine]: "Merge duplicate mesh vertices"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld mesh vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother
(0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Rebuilt]: "Resulting rebuilt mesh"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Box]: "Twisted Box to evaluate"
   - u [Parameter U]: "{u} parameter (values between 0.0 and 1.0 are inside the twisted box)"
   - v [Parameter V]: "{v} parameter (values between 0.0 and 1.0 are inside the twisted box)"
   - w [Parameter W]: "{w} parameter (values between 0.0 and 1.0 are inside the twisted box)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - E [Evaluation]: "Evaluation point at {uvw} coordinate"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if point is inside or on the twisted box, False if point is outside the twisted box"

## Mirror Cut Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the mesh cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the mesh within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the mesh from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut mesh"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the mesh and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut meshes are connected

0 = Split faces, with connection
1 = Remove faces, with connection
2 = Shrink faces, with connection
3 = Split faces, without connection
4 = Remove faces, without connection
5 = Shrink faces, without connection"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut mesh connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"
   - D [Divisions]: "Number of mesh faces per side of the mesh connection"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld mesh vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother
(0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut meshes"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut mesh set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mesh was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the mesh was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at S, 1.0 = Surface at S +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## To Polar
   (Tab: Vector > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Point]: "3D point to transcribe"
   - S [System]: "Plane defining polar coordinate space"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Phi]: "Planar angle in radians (counter-clockwise starting at the plane X-axis)"
   - T [Theta]: "Vertical angle in radians"
   - R [Radius]: "Distance from system origin to point"

   INPUTS:

   - B [Surface B]: "Surface to tween to"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface A, 1.0 = Surface B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surface"

## V-Ray Cosmos Asset
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Geometry)

   INPUTS:
   - Package [Asset Package]: "A Cosmos asset package name or ID and optionally a revision number. The ID is a GUID, the name is the string that is shown in the Cosmos Browser, and the revision is the publish date. The acceptable format is "id-or-name[/revision]"
Examples:
• Toaster 001
• cda5a22d-e0f7-48eb-a0d5-1e9631dedbb2
• Toaster 001 / 1614018486
• cda5a22d-e0f7-48eb-a0d5-1e9631dedbb2 / 1614018486"
   - Plane [Base Plane]: "Plane transformation for the Proxy.
A list of Plane inputs will add multiple instances of the same Proxy."
   - Scale [Scale]: "Scale factor for the Proxy.
A value of 1.0 is used by default.
Multiple Scale factors can be used."
   - Visible [Visible]: "Controls the proxy visibility"
   - Lights [Lights]: "Enables or disables all light sources in the Cosmos asset"
   - Intensity [Intensity multiplier]: "Multiplies the intensity of all light sources in the Cosmos asset"
   - Color [Color multiplier]: "Multiplies the color of all light sources in the Cosmos asset"

   OUTPUTS:
   - • V Geo [• V Geometry]: "V-Ray Geometry output."

----------------------------------------

   - G [Included Geometry]: "Objects matching filter criteria"

## Tween Through Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween through"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the guides between the curve extremes without considering the locations of the input curve set"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Medial Axis From Region TREE
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - Cs [Curves]: "Planar curves as tree"
   - A [Automatic]: "if automatic tolerance and distance will be choosen automatically"
   - Di [Distance]: "Distance between points on Curve to generate the Voronoi, limit of 20 000 points per curve"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance must be less tha Di/100, but in order to go fast not too low, choosen if automatic set to false"

   OUTPUTS:
   - Pl [Polyline]: "Polyline used, contour first then holes"
   - P [Plane]: "Plane for each region"
   - Ce [Voronoi Cells]: "Voronoi cells generated and cutted"
   - Ci [Circles]: "Circles inscribed"
   - Li [Lines]: "Lines linking the curve to the medial axis"
   - Ma [Medial Axis]: "Polylines representing Medial Axis"

## Helix//Spiral on Curve
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Spiral)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "The rail curve"
   - A [Angle of Start]: "Angle of start"
   - P [Pitch]: "The pitch. Positive values produce counter-clockwise orientation, negative values produce clockwise orientation."
   - TC [TurnCount]: "The turn count. If != 0, then the resulting helix will have this many turns. If = 0, then if pitch != 0 and the approximate distance between turns will be set to pitch. Positive values produce counter-clockwise orientation, negative values produce clockwise orientation. If pitch=0 and turnCount=0 curve will follow the perpandicular Frame"
   - R1 [R1]: "The starting radius. At least one radii must be nonzero. Negative values are allowed."
   - R2 [R2]: "The ending radius. At least one radii must be nonzero. Negative values are allowed"
   - N [N]: "Number of points to interpolate per turn. Must be greater than 4. When in doubt, use 12"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Helix]: "Helix"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Two Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Surface A]: "Surface to create twisted box array from"
   - B [Surface B]: "Surface to create twisted box array to"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surface starts, {u}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surface starts, {v}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface A, {w}1.0 = Surface B)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array between surfaces"

## Tween Through Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twisted boxes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Twisted Box at index 0, Index number of last Twisted Box = Twisted Box at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one twisted box to the next twisted box in the list is:
Index number of a twisted box = the twisted box at that index, Index number of the next twisted box = the next twisted box in the list, factors between the twisted box index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween twisted box halfway between the twisted box at index 2 and the twisted box at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Twisted Box at TB start, Factor 1.0 = Twisted Box at TB end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween twisted box"

----------------------------------------

## List Statistics
   (Tab: Bubalus_GH2.0 > Panel: List)

   INPUTS:
   - L [List]: "Data list to analyze"

   OUTPUTS:
   - L_i [Last Index]: "Last Index of the list "

----------------------------------------

   - i [Imaginary]: "Imaginary component of complex number"

## Flow on Mesh along Vectors Ext
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: CurveOnMesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh"
   - Vv [Vectors]: "A Vector for each vertex of the mesh"
   - P [Points]: "Points to start from (must not be at distance more than 10 to the mesh)"
   - N [Samples]: "Number of samples (parts of curve on mesh)"
   - D [Direction]: "Direction of flow, 0 for flow along vector, 1 for flow opposite to vector, 2 for both directions merged in one curve following the vectors"
   - S [StepSize]: "A relative stepsize [0.001, 1] "
   - Ns [StepsNumber]: "Number of steps of calculation in a triangle [1, 10000]"
   - T [Tolerance]: "A tolerance used to suppress close points"

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Curve approximation of field line through P"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at S, 1.0 = Surface at S +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points per direction) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing each direction by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Weighted Average Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces for averaging"
   - W [Weights]: "Collection of weights for each surface"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped averages, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped averages, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the curve cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the curve within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the curve from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut curves"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the curve and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut curves are connected

0 = Linear
1 = Tangency
2 = Curvature
3 = Meet Ends"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut curve connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut curves"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut curve set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the curve was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the curve was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Annotation Text Settings
   (Tab: Rhino > Panel: Annotations)

   INPUTS:
   - Text Settings [Text Settings]: "Text Settings"
   - Font [Font]: "Typography font"
   - Text Height [Text Height]: "Text Height"
   - Text Gap [Text Gap]: "Text Gap"
   - Draw Foward [Draw Foward]: "Text reads forward when viewed from behind"
   - Mask Frame [Mask Frame]: "Mask frame: 
0) None
1) Rectangular
2) Capsule
"
   - Mask Colour [Mask Colour]: "Mask Colour. If left empty, the background colour will be used."
   - Mask Margins [Mask Margins]: "Mask Margins"
   - View Oriented [View Oriented]: "Text orientated to view"
   - Horizontal Alignment [Horizontal Alignment]: "Horizontal text alignment: 
0) Left - Attach at left of text lines (Independent of glyphs being displayed)
1) Center - Attach point at center of text horizontal advance (not glyph bounding box)
2) Right - Attach point at right text horizontal advance (not glyph bounding box)
3) Auto - Used for Leaders only. Attach point adjusts to Right or Left depending on leader tail direction in view
If tail direction is to the Left, alignment is Right. If tail direction is to the Right, alignment is Left."
   - Vertical Alignment [Vertical Alignment]: "Vertical text alignment: 
0) Top - Attach to top of an "I" on the first line. (Independent of glyphs being displayed)
3) Middle - Attach to middle of text vertical advance. (Independent of glyphs being displayed)
5) Bottom - Attach to the basline of the last line. (Independent of glyphs being displayed.)
"
   - Fit Text [Fit Text]: "Fit text: 
0) Auto - Display inside when space permits
1) Text Inside - Force text inside extensions
2) Text Right - Force text outside to the right of extensions
3) Text Left - Force text outside to the left of extensions
4) Text Hint Right - Move text outside to the right of extensions when it won't fit inside
5) Text Hint Left - Move text outside to the left of extensions when it won't fit inside
"

   OUTPUTS:
   - Text Settings [Text Settings]: "Text Settings"
   - Font [Font]: "Typography font"
   - Text Height [Text Height]: "Text Height"
   - Text Gap [Text Gap]: "Text Gap"
   - Draw Foward [Draw Foward]: "Text reads forward when viewed from behind"
   - Mask Frame [Mask Frame]: "Mask frame: 
0) None
1) Rectangular
2) Capsule
"
   - Mask Colour [Mask Colour]: "Mask Colour. If left empty, the background colour will be used."
   - Mask Margins [Mask Margins]: "Mask Margins"
   - View Oriented [View Oriented]: "Text orientated to view"
   - Horizontal Alignment [Horizontal Alignment]: "Horizontal text alignment: 
0) Left - Attach at left of text lines (Independent of glyphs being displayed)
1) Center - Attach point at center of text horizontal advance (not glyph bounding box)
2) Right - Attach point at right text horizontal advance (not glyph bounding box)
3) Auto - Used for Leaders only. Attach point adjusts to Right or Left depending on leader tail direction in view
If tail direction is to the Left, alignment is Right. If tail direction is to the Right, alignment is Left."
   - Vertical Alignment [Vertical Alignment]: "Vertical text alignment: 
0) Top - Attach to top of an "I" on the first line. (Independent of glyphs being displayed)
3) Middle - Attach to middle of text vertical advance. (Independent of glyphs being displayed)
5) Bottom - Attach to the basline of the last line. (Independent of glyphs being displayed.)
"
   - Fit Text [Fit Text]: "Fit text: 
0) Auto - Display inside when space permits
1) Text Inside - Force text inside extensions
2) Text Right - Force text outside to the right of extensions
3) Text Left - Force text outside to the left of extensions
4) Text Hint Right - Move text outside to the right of extensions when it won't fit inside
5) Text Hint Left - Move text outside to the left of extensions when it won't fit inside
"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - Cl [Colors]: "Set of colors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Color at Cl start, 1.0 = Color at Cl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Color at index 0, Index number of last color = Color at last index)

The tween factor range from one color to the next color in the list is:
Index number of a color = the color at that index, Index number of the next color = the next color in the list, factors between the color index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween color halfway between the color at index 2 and the color at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input color set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input color set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - a [Alpha]: "Include the transparencies (alpha values) of the colors in the tweening"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween color"

----------------------------------------

   - Crvs [Curves]: "Curve list to sort for duplicates."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Unique [Unique Curves]: "List of unique curves."
   - Indices [Indices]: "Sorted indices."

## Twisted Box Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array between"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surface starts, {u}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surface starts, {v}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between each surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface at S, {w}1.0 = Surface at S +1)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between surfaces"

----------------------------------------
