## Tween Through Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween through"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

   INPUTS:

   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along the curves {u} domain for mesh faces ({u}0.0 = Curve start, {u}1.0 = Curve end)
(unless Length is true or Angle is not 0.0)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around the curve {v} domain for mesh faces ({v}0.0 = Revolve min, {v}1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the curves curvatures"
   - L [Lengths]: "If True, the curves mesh face divisions are defined by the lengths between its control points instead of the {u} parameters

(useful for conforming mesh face divisions to each segment of a polyline curve)"
   - A [Angle]: "If Angle is not 0.0, the curves mesh face divisions are defined by angle accuracy in degrees instead of the {u} parameters

(useful for conforming mesh face divisions to the curvature of the curve)"
   - R [Rotation]: "Rotation of the pipe mesh radius around the curve, in degrees"
   - E [End Type]: "Determines how to end the pipe mesh

0 = None
1 = Flat
2 = Round"

## Reduce Mesh By Faces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to reduce"
   - F [Face Count]: "Target face count. This number is just a target goal, face count in resulting reduced mesh may differ"
   - A [Accuracy]: "Accuracy of reduction (1 = Least, 10 = Most)"
   - T [Face Type]: "0 = Default (face types are a direct result of the reduction)
1 = Quadrangulate if possible (gets applied after reduction, may change face count)
2 = Triangulate all (gets applied after reduction, may change face count)"
   - D [Distort]: "If true, mesh will reduce to reach the desired face count
If false, mesh will reduce only until the point at which the mesh shape would be required to change"
   - N [Normalize]: "More equally distribute the mesh face sizes"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Reduced]: "Resulting reduced mesh"
   - C [Count Difference]: "Difference in face count between the original mesh and the reduced mesh"

## Normalize Data
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Data Sets)

   INPUTS:
   - Data [Data]: "The data set to change."
   - Columns [Columns]: "The names of the columns in the data set to normalize."
   - Fix Zero [Fix Zero]: "Whether to map zero to zero, preserving sparsity. When fixZero is false, the normalized interval is [0,1] and the distribution of the normalized values depends on the normalization mode. When fixZero is set to true, the normalized interval is [−1,1] with the distribution of the normalized values depending on the normalization mode, but the behavior is different. With this method, the distribution depends on how far away the number is from 0, resulting in the number with the largest distance being mapped to 1 if its a positive number or -1 if its a negative number.The distance from 0 will affect the distribution with a majority of numbers that are closer together normalizing towards 0."
   - Mode [Normalization Mode]: "Normalization Mode: 
 (0) Min Max - rescale the input by the difference between the minimum and maximum values in the data.
 (1) Mean Variance - subtract the mean (of the data) and divide by the variance (of the data)
 (2) Log Mean Variance - normalize based on the logarithm of the data
 (3) Normalize Binning - assign the input value to a bin index and divide by the number of bins to produce a float value between 0 and 1. The bin boundaries are calculated to evenly distribute the data across bins."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Data [Data]: "The modified data set."

----------------------------------------

## Write to Text File
   (Tab: Wombat > Panel: Files / Interop)

   INPUTS:
   - R [Run]: "Set to true to stream or write the text. Always on by default!"
   - T [Text to write]: "The list of strings you wish to write to a text file"
   - P [File Path]: "The path to which you want to write"
   - A [Append]: "Set to true to append text"
   - N [New Only]: "Set to true to only add new lines not currently in the document - only applies in "append" mode."

   OUTPUTS:
   - D [Done]: "True on successful completion"

## Average Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves for averaging"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped averages, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped averages, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input curves"

Input a curve to exrude along a curve
Input a point to extrude to a point"

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component."

## Tween Through Points On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Point at P start, Factor 1.0 = Point at P end)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on curve"

----------------------------------------

## Curve to Lines and Arcs
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve that will be transformed to lines and arcs"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Maximum allowable deviation"
   - AT [AngleTolerance]: "Maximum angle tolerance use [0.01 ro 0.2]"
   - R [RhMethod]: "If true, it will be just the Rhinocommon method used"
   - H [Heal]: "If true, it will replace arc that are not aligned with [AngleTolerance/100, AngleTolerance]"

## Twisted Box Curve Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted boxes along"
   - X [Sizes X]: "A list of domain sizes for the twisted box curve {x} dimensions at every {t} division parameter"
   - Y [Sizes Y]: "A list of domain sizes for the twisted box curve {y} dimensions at every {t} division parameter"
   - t [Parameters T]: "Division parameters along curve domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box curve around the twisted box centers at every {t} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box curve around the curve at every {t} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box curve is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along curve"

## Twisted Box Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array between"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surface starts, {u}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surface starts, {v}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between each surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface at S, {w}1.0 = Surface at S +1)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the parameters {w} interpolation path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Numbers
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Number)

   INPUTS:
   - N [Numbers]: "Set of numbers to mirror cut"
   - Mi [Mirror Index]: "Index that the kept side of the number set cut gets mirrored across.
Negative index reverses the number set and removes from the top."
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (False = Mirror after index, True = Mirror before index)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut number set (removes the duplicate number in the middle of the set)"
   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the number set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut number set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut number set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mirror index intersected the number set, False if the mirror index did not intersect the number set"

----------------------------------------

## Recursive Morph Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - B [Base Mesh]: "Base mesh to morph the first mesh geometry onto its faces
(best results if using a lower poly mesh and smoothing the result mesh)"
   - N [Steps]: "Number of recursive morphing steps

WARNING: Recursion creates new meshes on each mesh face potentially at an exponetial level. Step number values above 3 could create a lot of mesh faces. Please be sure to save your work in case your computer freezes with higher step numbers."
   - M [Meshes]: "A list of mesh geometries to morph, one mesh geometry for every recursive morphing step
(best results if using lower poly meshes and smoothing the result mesh)"
   - R [References]: "A list of reference boxes to morph from, one reference box for every recursive morphing step
(typically the bounding box of each mesh geometry to morph)"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses offset from mesh faces for morph heights, one thickness for every recursive morphing step"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld mesh vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother
(0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Morphed]: "Resulting recursive morphed mesh"

----------------------------------------

1 = Chord

## Tween Consecutive Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween between"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves along curve"

## Unroll Polysurface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - Ps [Polysurface]: "Polysurface (Brep) or surface to unroll"
   - Pl [Plane]: "Optional plane to unroll to, if no plane is set the world XY plane is used"
   - P [Points]: "Optional points to unroll with the polysurface (Brep) or surface, points should lay exactly on the polysurface (Brep) faces or surface"
   - C [Curves]: "Optional curves to unroll with the polysurface (Brep) or surface, curves should lay exactly on the polysurface (Brep) faces or surface"
   - E [Explode]: "Optional number which will explode the unrolled polysurface (Brep) faces as a disconnected linear array spaced apart by the amount of the number, unrolled points and curves will follow"
   - a [Area Tolerance]: "Tolerance for the allowable surface area deviation that determines if the polysurface (Brep) or surface can be unrolled
(if omitted document tolerance is used)"
   - e [Edge Tolerance]: "Tolerance for the allowable surface edge deviation that determines if the polysurface (Brep) or surface can be unrolled
(if omitted document tolerance is used)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Unrolled]: "Resulting unrolled polysurface (Brep) faces or surface"
   - Up [Unrolled Points]: "The points which unrolled with the polysurface (Brep) faces or surface"
   - Uc [Unrolled Curves]: "The curves which unrolled with the polysurface (Brep) faces or surface"

----------------------------------------

## Seam To Curve Corner
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Closed curve with corners to adjust the seam of"
   - G [Guide]: "Optional guide point to find the closest corner to (will override the initial seam location)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - A [Adjusted]: "Resulting curve with seam adjusted to the closest corner"
   - P [Points]: "Point at the curve seam adjusted to the closest corner"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if curve is closed with a seam at a corner, False if curve is opened or does not have corners"

----------------------------------------

## Run Loop
   (Tab: Anemone > Panel: Internalized)

   INPUTS:
   - I [Iterations]: "Number of loops"

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

----------------------------------------

## Divide Length with Reference
   (Tab: PanelingTools > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:

   - D [Length]: "Length"
   - P [RefPt]: "Reference point"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P start, 1.0 = Point at P end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input point set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input point set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array through"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domain (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domain (0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through surfaces {w} domain (0.0 = {w}Surface at index 0, Index number of last surface = {w}Surface at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last surface, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Colors]: "Set of colors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Color at index 0, Index number of last color = Color at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one color to the next color in the list is:
Index number of a color = the color at that index, Index number of the next color = the next color in the list, factors between the color index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween color halfway between the color at index 2 and the color at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Color at C start, Factor 1.0 = Color at C end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - a [Alpha]: "Tween the transparencies (alpha values) of the colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween color"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Film Sensitivity
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Render)

   INPUTS:
   - EV [Exposure Value]: "The exposure value"
   - F [F-Number]: "The aperture (f-number) parameter determines the lens speed and consequently the brightness of the image.
Additionally, the f-number will affect the Depth of Field of the camera.
The smaller the f-number is, the more narrow the depth of field will be."
   - SS [Shutter Speed (1/s)]: "The shutter speed parameter determines the exposure time for the virtual camera.
The longer this time is (small shutter speed value), the brighter the image would be.
In reverse - if the exposure time is shorter (high Shutter speed value), the image would get darker."

   OUTPUTS:
   - ISO [Film Sensitivity]: "The film speed (ISO) parameter determines the sensitivity of the film and consequently the brightness of the image.
If the ISO value is high (film is more sensitive to the light), the image is brighter.
Lower ISO values mean that the film is less sensitive and produces a darker image."

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Tube Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array along"
   - R [Radii]: "A list of outer radii for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter, offset inward from the outer radius corners"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Radii, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - O [Offsets]: "A list of domain defined offset center locations of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve at every {u} division parameter (0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the radii centers at every {u} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the curve at every {u} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

## Tween Through Planes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl start, 1.0 = Plane at Pl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input plane set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input plane set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane"

## AutoCAD Export Option

The V-Ray Camera output angle can be used here to orient the light based on the camera."

## K-Means Clustering Tester
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Models)

   INPUTS:
   - Model [Model]: "Trained Regression model."
   - Testing Data [Testing Data Set]: "The testing data set."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Predictions [Predictions]: "Predictions"
   - Centroids [Cluster Centroids]: "Returns the centroid of each cluster."
   - Avg Distance [Average Distance]: "For the K-Means algorithm, the 'score' is the distance from the centroid to the example. The average score is, therefore, a measure of proximity of the examples to cluster centroids. In other words, it is a measure of 'cluster tightness'. Note however, that this metric will only decrease if the number of clusters is increased, and in the extreme case (where each distinct example is its own cluster) it will be equal to zero."
   - Davies-Bouldin [Davies-Bouldin Index]: "The Davies-Bouldin Index is measure of the how much scatter is in the cluster and the cluster separation."

----------------------------------------

## Weaverbird's Mesh Thicken
   (Tab: Wb > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh/Curves]: "The open or closed mesh, or closed curves list, to modify"
   - D [Distance]: "The list of distanced to use in the construction of the new internal vertices. One distance/vertex"
   - T [OffsetType]: "Definition of distance for new vertices

0: Distance On Diagonals. The measurement on the diagonal decides the offset.
1: Hypotenuse Average. Trigonometrical. This setting is experimental..
2: Planes Intersections. Planes intersections, works best with valence-three vertices. This setting is experimental.."

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [Output Mesh/Curves]: "The mesh after the offset"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves along guide curve to tween through"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from first Curve in C to last Curve in C)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Curve at C start, Factor 1.0 = Curve at C end)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twisted boxes to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Twisted Box at TB, 1.0 = Twisted Box at TB +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input twisted box set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween twisted boxes"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Pipe
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Pipe-like surface to create twisted boxes along the inside of"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along pipe-like surface {u} domain (0.0 = {u}start, 1.0 = {u}end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v¹ [Parameter V1]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the first and fifth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the lowest number of the {v} parameters"
   - v² [Parameter V2]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the second and sixth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v1} but a lower number than parameter {v3}"
   - v³ [Parameter V3]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the third and seventh corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be a larger number than parameter {v2} but a lower number than parameter {v4}"
   - v⁴ [Parameter V4]: "Division parameter along pipe-like surface {v} domain that the fourth and eigth corners of the twisted boxes are on
(0.0 = {v}start, 1.0 = {v}end)

For best results parameter should be between 0 and 1 and be the largest number of the {v} parameters"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input pipe-like surface curvature"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the twisted box flow if they are not flowing in the correct direction along the the inside of the pipe-like surface"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along the inside of the pipe-like surface"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:

Additionally, the f-number will affect the Depth of Field of the camera.
The smaller the f-number is, the more narrow the depth of field will be."

## Shear Angle
   (Tab: Transform > Panel: Affine)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Base geometry"
   - P [Base]: "Base plane"
   - Ax [Angle X]: "Rotation around {x} axis in radians"
   - Ay [Angle Y]: "Rotation around {y} axis in radians"

   OUTPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Sheared geometry"

----------------------------------------

   - Wv [Weights]: "Weights for each vertex of the mesh"
   - Fv [Fixed]: "Boolean value for each vertex, if fixed is true weight will not change, by default not fixed"
   - A [Algorithm]: "Type of method used, if 0 Cotan, if 1 Length, if 2 Uniform"
   - B [Boundary]: "If true, values will not change on boundary"
   - N [Steps]: "Number of steps"

## Mirror Cut Transforms
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - X [Transforms]: "Set of transforms to mirror cut"
   - Mi [Mirror Index]: "Index that the kept side of the transform set cut gets mirrored across.
Negative index reverses the mirror set and removes from the top."
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (False = Mirror after index, True = Mirror before index)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut transform set (removes the duplicate transform in the middle of the set)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut transform set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut transform set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mirror index intersected the transform set, False if the mirror index did not intersect the transform set"

## Tween Consecutive Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at S, 1.0 = Surface at S +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surfaces"

----------------------------------------

   - Intensity [Intensity]: "Light source intensity. Calculated in the specified units."
   - Units [Intensity Units]: "Specifies the light unit of measurement.
Using correct units is essential when working with physical camera exposure.
The light will automatically take the scene units scale into consideration to produce the correct result for the scale being worked in."
   - Shape [Shape]: "Controls whether the Dome light covers the entire scene or only the half above the horizon line."
   - Plane [Base Plane]: "Controls the orientation of the dome light defining the equatorial plane of the imaginary sphere encompassing the entire model. The texture mapping will match this plane as well. The X and Z axes define the texture UV coordinate system."

## One Hot Encoding
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Data Sets)

   INPUTS:
   - Data [Data]: "The data set to change."
   - Columns [Columns]: "The names of the columns in the data set to encode."
   - Output Kind [Output Kind]: "Output Kind: 
 (1) Bag - produces one vector such that each slot stores the number of occurances of the corresponding value in the input vector. Each slot in this vector corresponds to a value in the dictionary, so its length is the size of the built dictionary. Indicator and Bag differ simply in how the bit-vectors generated from individual slots in the input column are aggregated: for Indicator they are concatenated and for Bag they are added. When the source column is a Scalar, the Indicator and Bag options are identical.
 (2) Indicator - produces an indicator vector. Each slot in this vector corresponds to a category in the dictionary, so its length is the size of the built dictionary. If a value is not found in the dictioray, the output is the zero vector.
 (3) Key - produces keys in a KeyDataViewType column. If the input column is a vector, the output contains a vectory key type, where each slot of the vector corresponds to the respective slot of the input vector. If a category is not found in the bulit dictionary, it is assigned the value zero.
 (4) Binary - produces a binary encoded vector to represent the values found in the dictionary that are present in the input column. If a value in the input column is not found in the dictionary, the output is the zero vector.
"

   OUTPUTS:
   - Data [Data]: "The modified data set."

----------------------------------------

   - T [Target]: "Target length of curve divisions"
   - D [Division Type]: "Determines which closest division length is used

0 = Nearest (The closest length to the target length)
1 = Floor (The closest length smaller than or equal to the target length)
2 = Ceiling (The closest length larger than or equal to the target length)"

## Tween Through Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, numbers between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curve on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input curve set"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Diamond Grid
   (Tab: LunchBox > Panel: Panels)

   INPUTS:
   - Srf [Surface]: "A surface to panelize"
   - U [U Divisions]: "Divisions in the surface U direction."
   - V [V Divisions]: "Divisions in the surface V direction."

   OUTPUTS:
   - C1 [Corner Point 1]: "The first corner point"
   - C2 [Corner Point 2]: "The second corner point"
   - C3 [Corner Point 3]: "The third corner point"
   - C4 [Corner Point 4]: "The fourth corner point"
   - MPt [Mid Point]: "The midpoint of the quad."
   - N [Normals]: "Normal vector at midpoint."

## Twisted Box Tube Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array along"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - R [Radii]: "A list of outer radii for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter, offset inward from the outer radius corners"
   - O [Offsets]: "A list of domain defined offset center locations of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve at every {u} division parameter (0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the radii centers at every {u} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the curve at every {u} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, numbers between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on curve"

## Tween Through Points On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P start, 1.0 = Point at P end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input point set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input point set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Screen-Oriented Mesh
   (Tab: Human > Panel: Display)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to display to screen. Make sure the mesh is positioned at (or near) the world origin."
   - L [Location]: "The location to display the mesh"
   - S [Size Factor]: "A multiplier on the scale. Use this to adjust the size of the mesh in the display."
   - C [Color]: "The color to display the mesh. This will not override per-vertex mesh colors."
   - D [Depth]: "A value that controls the Z-depth of the mesh display. 
Higher numbers will appear in front of most objects - lower will go behind.
However, values that are too high may cause the display to disappear completely."
   - A [Absolute]: "If true, objects remain a fixed size relative to world dimenions - if false, objects are always the same size relative to the screen"
   - T [Bitmap Texture]: "If provided, a bitmap texture for the mesh. Use texture mapping components to align texture."

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

## Slide Curve Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to slide along guide curve"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to slide along"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to slide along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Slide factor (0.0 = Slide start, 1.0 = Slide end)"
   - A [Align]: "Align the slide curve to the input curve, when using one guide curve"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped slides, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped slides, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Slid]: "Resulting curve slid along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, numbers between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on surface"

   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Textures)

   INPUTS:
   - Type [Ramp Type]: "Controls the direction and the shape of the gradient ramp.
Changing the type will not affect the color and position of the control points"
   - Interpolation [Interpolation]: "Changes the color interpolation method.
Changing the option will change the color transition curve between the control point
None - Disables the transition"
   - Colors [Colors]: "Control point colors. One per position"
   - Positions [Positions]: "Position of the control point in a normalized domain. One per color"
   - • UVW [• UVW Placement]: "Specifies the texture placement within the UVW space of the object"

   OUTPUTS:

## Average SubD
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: SubD)

   INPUTS:
   - SD [SubDs]: "Set of SubDs for averaging"
   - Cr [Crease Type]: "Determines how SubDs are creased (0 = None, 1 = At Creases, 2 = At Edges)"
   - Co [Corner Type]: "Determines how SubDs are cornered (0 = None, 1 = At Corners)"
   - Iv [Interpolate Vertices]: "If True, SubDs are interpolated through their control polygon vertices"

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input SubDs"

----------------------------------------

   - CP [Camera Plane]: "The camera plane for each viewport"

## Tween Consecutive Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Mesh at M, 1.0 = Mesh at M +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - C [Colored Type]: "Determines how mesh vertex colors are tweened

0 = None
1 = Fast
2 = Accurate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween meshes"

----------------------------------------

## Create CSV
   (Tab: LunchBox > Panel: Data)

   INPUTS:
   - Headers [Data Grid Headers]: "A list of Header names for the Data Grid."
   - Values [Value Tree]: "A tree structure of numeric values. (Default behavior is to treat branches as columns.)"
   - Delimit [Delimiter]: "A delimiting value for the CSV string. (typically a comma)"
   - Quotes [Quote Items]: "Include quoation marks around CSV headers and values."

   OUTPUTS:
   - CSV [CSV String]: "The CSV String."

   OUTPUTS:

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Material Simple
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Materials)

   INPUTS:
   - Diffuse [Diffuse]: "Diffuse Color of the material."
   - Reflection [Reflection]: "Reflection Color of the material.
Black color disables the reflections."
   - Glossiness [Glossiness]: "Reflection Glossiness value.
A value of 1.0 means perfect mirror-like reflection.
Lower values produce blurry reflections."
   - IOR [IOR]: "Reflection IOR value.
The reflection strength of this material depends on the viewing angle of the surface.
Bigger IOR values will make perpendicular(to the camera ray) surfaces reflect stronger."
   - Opacity [Opacity]: "Opacity Color of the material.
White color makes the material 100% opaque.
Darker color values will make it transparent."
   - Emission [Emission]: "Emission Color of the material."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Mtl [• Material]: "V-Ray material output that can be connected to V-Ray Geometries."

----------------------------------------

## Tween Two Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Mesh A]: "Mesh to tween from"
   - B [Mesh B]: "Mesh to tween to"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Mesh A, 1.0 = Mesh B)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween mesh"

----------------------------------------

   - uF [Factor U]: "Tween factor {u} (0.0 = Domain² {u} at I², 1.0 = Domain² {u} at I² +1)"
   - vF [Factor V]: "Tween factor {v} (0.0 = Domain² {v} at I², 1.0 = Domain² {v} at I² +1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween domain²s"

   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters for layers along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Input Twisted Box, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - H [Hollow]: "Remove the center twisted box"

   INPUTS:

   - W [Print Width]: "Print Width or Offset Distance or Distance between Patterns"
   - B [Relative Bridge Width]: "Bridge Width Factor relative to Print Width"
   - dX [Pattern Length Factor]: "Pattern length factor relative to Print Width"
   - dY [Pattern Height Factor]: "Pattern height factor relative to Print Width"
   - Bo [Use Border Curves]: "If true use the border curves"
   - Sf [Smooth Factor]: "Factor to smooth the Pattern [0, 1["
   - S [Relative Search Distance]: "Search factor relative to Print Width"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance used to convert the curves to polyline"
   - P [Parallel Calculation]: "If true use parallel computation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Polylines]: "Polylines sorted used as borders, first polyline is the outside, others are the holes"
   - Pl [Planes]: "Planes"
   - Pa [Patterns Closed]: "Closed curves patterns"
   - Po [Patterns Opened]: "Opened curves patterns"
   - B [Bridges]: "Bridges"
   - S [Single Line Fill]: "Single line fill, if OK just one polyline"

## Tween Consecutive Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the mesh cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the mesh within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the mesh from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut mesh"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the mesh and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut meshes are connected

0 = Split faces, with connection
1 = Remove faces, with connection
2 = Shrink faces, with connection
3 = Split faces, without connection
4 = Remove faces, without connection
5 = Shrink faces, without connection"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut mesh connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"
   - D [Divisions]: "Number of mesh faces per side of the mesh connection"
   - W [Weld Vertices]: "Weld mesh vertices that are within a specified proximity of eachother
(0.0 = No weld, Number greater than 0 = Weld vertices within proximity of the number)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut meshes"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut mesh set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mesh was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the mesh was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curves on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves on surface"

## Tween Through Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - Cl [Colors]: "Set of colors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Color at Cl start, 1.0 = Color at Cl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Color at index 0, Index number of last color = Color at last index)

The tween factor range from one color to the next color in the list is:
Index number of a color = the color at that index, Index number of the next color = the next color in the list, factors between the color index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween color halfway between the color at index 2 and the color at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input color set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input color set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - a [Alpha]: "Include the transparencies (alpha values) of the colors in the tweening"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween color"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:

## V-Ray Light Spot
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Lighting)

   INPUTS:
   - On [On]: "Enables or disables the light source."
   - Position [Position]: "Light source location (point position).
If a list of input Positions is connected multiple lights will be generated.
Note: The number of input positions will determine the lights count."
   - Target [Target]: "The light Position and Target combined determine the targeted light orientation vector."
   - Color [Color]: "Light source color."
   - Intensity [Intensity]: "Light source intensity. Calculated in the specified units."
   - Units [Intensity Units]: "Specifies the light unit of measurement.
Using correct units is essential when working with physical camera exposure.
The light will automatically take the scene units scale into consideration to produce the correct result for the scale being worked in."
   - Cone [Cone Angle]: "Specifies the angle of the light cone formed by the light.
The value should be specified in degrees."
   - Penumbra [Penumbra Angle]: "Specifies the angle within the light cone at which the light begins to transform from full strength to no lighting.
When set to 0, there is no transition and the light produces a harsh edge.
The value should be specified in degrees."
   - Shadow Softness [Shadow Softness]: "Sets the shadow softness. Zero (0.0) makes the shadows perfectly sharp, larger values produce blurrier shadows."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Light [• Add Light]: "Light output that can be connected to a Renderer"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to create twisted box array on"
   - T [Thickness]: "Overall thickness of the twisted box array from the mesh, offset from the faces"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness domain (0.0 = Mesh, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array on mesh"

----------------------------------------

## Vector World
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Vector)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Plane]: "Base plane for vector world orientation and location"
   - T [Direction Type]: "Determines the vector world directions to use

0 = Cardinal
1 = InterCardinal
2 = Cardinal + InterCardinal"
   - D [Dimensionality]: "True for 2D. False for 3D"

   OUTPUTS:
   - V [Vectors]: "Resulting axis aligned vectors"
   - L [Lines]: "Line representation of the vectors"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Array
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - B [Box]: "Box to create twisted box array in"
   - x [Parameters X]: "Division parameters along the box {x} domain (0.0 = {x}start, 1.0 = {x}end)

For best results {x} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - y [Parameters Y]: "Division parameters along the box {y} domain (0.0 = {y}start, 1.0 = {y}end)

For best results {y} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - z [Parameters Z]: "Division parameters along the box {z} domain (0.0 = {z}start, 1.0 = {z}end)

For best results {z} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array"

----------------------------------------

   - S [Spacing]: "The minimum spacing between items"

   - W [Max Pixels Width]: "Maximum number of pixels in width  [20, 10000]"

## Revolve Unsplit Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Profile]: "Profile curve or surface to revolve"
   - A [Axis]: "Axis line to revolve around"
   - R [Revolution]: "Domain of revolution in degrees (0 = Revolve start, 360 = Revolve end)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Unsplit]: "Resulting untrimmed single unsplit revolved surface

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twisted boxes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Twisted Box at index 0, Index number of last Twisted Box = Twisted Box at last index)

The tween factor range from one twisted box to the next twisted box in the list is:
Index number of a twisted box = the twisted box at that index, Index number of the next twisted box = the next twisted box in the list, numbers between the twisted box index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween twisted box halfway between the twisted box at index 2 and the twisted box at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween twisted box"

----------------------------------------

## Lbfgs Maximum Entropy Multiclass Classifier
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Trainer Types)

   INPUTS:
   - Non-Negativity [Enforce Non-Negativity]: "Enforce non-negative weights."
   - L1 Regularization [L1 Regularization]: "The L1 regularization weight."
   - L2 Regularization [L2 Regularization]: "The L2 regularization weight."
   - History Size [History Size]: "Number of previous iterations to remember for estimating the Hessian. Lower values mean faster but less accurate estimates."
   - Tolerance [Optimization Tolerance]: "Tolerance parameter for optimization convergence. (Low = slower, more accurate)."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Trainer Type [Trainer Type]: "The trainer used for machine learning problems."

----------------------------------------

## Aerial Perspective
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Environment)

   INPUTS:
   - Sun [Sun Light]: "Specifies the Sun the aerial perspective effect is connected to."
   - Visibility [Visibility Range]: "Specifies the distance in meters at which the fog has absorbed 90% of the light coming from the objects behind it.
Lower values make the fog appear more dense, while larger values reduce the effect of the aerial perspective."
   - Height [Atmosphere Height]: "Controls the height of the atmosphere layers in meters.
Lower values can be used for artistic effects."
   - Multiplier [Light Multiplier]: "Controls the amount of sunlight scattered from the atmospheric effect. Value of 1.0 is physically accurate."
   - Color [Filter Color]: "Affects the color of the unscattered light."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Volumetric [• Environment Volume]: "Environment volume shader"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:

----------------------------------------

## Tween Two Curves Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Curve A]: "Curve along guide curve to tween from"
   - B [Curve B]: "Curve along guide curve to tween to"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from Curve A to Curve B)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve A, 1.0 = Curve B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve along curve"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Union]: "The Set Union of A and B."

## Twisted Box Tube Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array along"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - D [Diameters]: "A list of outer diameters for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter, offset inward from the outer diameter corners"
   - O [Offsets]: "A list of domain defined offset center locations of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve at every {u} division parameter (0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the diameter centers at every {u} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the curve at every {u} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Render)

   INPUTS:

Controls the animation lenght."
   - Start [Range Start]: "Specifies the first frame from a range of frames to be rendered"
   - End [Range End]: "Specifies the last frame from a range of frames to be rendered"

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Timeline [• Timeline]: "V-Ray Timeline output.
Can be connected to the V-Ray Render / Timeline slot."
   - Frame [Current Frame]: "Outputs the current animation frame as an integer value.
This output can be used for animating different definition parameters"
   - Fraction [Current Fraction]: "Outputs the current animation frame as a fraction of the slider length - a value in the range 0.0 to 1.0 (inclusive).
Example: If the timeline frames count is set to 11 and the slider position is at 5, the fraction float output will be 0.5
This output can be used for animating different definition parameters."

## V-Ray Light IES
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Lighting)

   INPUTS:
   - On [On]: "Enables or disables the light source."
   - Plane [Base plane]: "The IES light base plane, where its origin is positioned and orientated along."
   - File [File]: "Specifies an .ies file to use for the current light."
   - Color [Color]: "Light source color."
   - Power [Power]: "Specifies the strength of the light to override the intensity specified in the .ies file. If the value is set to 0 then the power from the IES profile is used."
   - Shape [Shape]: "Determines the shape of the light when calculating Soft Shadows.
By default, VRayLightIES will use the shape information stored in the .ies file."
   - Diameter [Diameter]: "The diameter of the light shape."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Light [• Add Light]: "Light output that can be connected to a Renderer"

## Tween Through Points On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P start, 1.0 = Point at P end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the curve between the point extremes without considering the locations of the input point set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on curve"

----------------------------------------

   OUTPUTS:
   - F [Field]: "Field"

## Tween Two Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Surface A]: "Surface to tween from"
   - B [Surface B]: "Surface to tween to"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface A, 1.0 = Surface B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points per direction) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing each direction by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surface"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Numbers
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Number)

   INPUTS:
   - N [Numbers]: "Set of numbers to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Number at N start, 1.0 = Number at N end), unless Normalized is False."
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Number at index 0, Index number of last number = Number at last index)

The tween factor range from one number to the next number in the list is:
Index number of a number = the number at that index, Index number of the next number = the next number in the list, factors between the number index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween number halfway between the number at index 2 and the number at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated between the extremes of the input number set without considering the locations of the input number set"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween number"

----------------------------------------

   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the shell"
   - F [Face Merge]: "Merge coplanar polysurface faces into single surfaces

WARNING: this option may be heavy depending on the amount of coplanar faces, please be sure to save before use"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Shell]: "Resulting polysurface shell (Brep)"

Index number of a twisted box = the twisted box at that index, Index number of the next twisted box = the next twisted box in the list, numbers between the twisted box index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween twisted box halfway between the twisted box at index 2 and the twisted box at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root

## Angular Dimensions (Mesh)
   (Tab: Display > Panel: Dimensions)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to annotate"
   - T [Text]: "Dimension text"
   - S [Size]: "Dimension size"
   - F [Length Factor]: "Radius of dimension as part of edge length."
   - A0 [Minimum Angle]: "Threshold angle below which dimensions are not drawn."
   - A1 [Maximum Angle]: "Threshold angle above which dimensions are not drawn."

   OUTPUTS:
   - (None)

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Light Sun
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Lighting)

   INPUTS:
   - On [On]: "Enables or disables the light source."
   - Position [Position]: "Light source location (point position).
If a list of input Positions is connected multiple lights will be generated.
Note: The number of input positions will determine the lights count."
   - Target [Target]: "The light Position and Target combined determine the targeted light orientation vector."
   - Intensity [Intensity]: "Light source intensity. Calculated in the specified units."
   - Filter Color [Filter Color]: "Tints the automatic Sun light color. Note that the light color also depends on the Sun's altitude."
   - Ground Color [Ground Color]: "The Ground Albedo color."
   - Caustics Radius [Caustics Emit Radius]: "Defines the area around the V-Ray Sun from where the photons will be shot."
   - Caustics Subdivs [Caustics Subdivisions]: "Determines the number of caustic photons emitted from the light source.
Lower values mean more noisy results, but will render faster.
Higher values produce smoother results but take more time."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Light [• Add Light]: "Light output that can be connected to a Renderer"
