## Tween Through Vectors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Vector)

   INPUTS:
   - V [Vectors]: "Set of vectors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Vector at V start, 1.0 = Vector at V end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Vector at index 0, Index number of last vector = Vector at last index)

The tween factor range from one vector to the next vector in the list is:
Index number of a vector = the vector at that index, Index number of the next vector = the next vector in the list, factors between the vector index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween vector halfway between the vector at index 2 and the vector at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input vector set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input vector set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween vector"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Planes On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween plane on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl start, 1.0 = Plane at Pl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input plane set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input plane set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane on surface"

----------------------------------------

   - I [Intersected]: "True if the points trimmed the curve, False if the points did not trim the curve"

   - S [Surface]: "Surface to offset curve away from"
   - D [Distance]: "Offset distance away from surface"
   - B [Both Sides]: "Optional offset distance to offset both sides, use the inverse number of the distance to offset in the opposite direction
(so if distance is a positive number then use a negative number and vice versa)"
   - T [Cap Type]: "Determines how to cap the curve ends

0 = None
1 = Linear
2 = Tangency
3 = Curvature"

Index number of a number = the number at that index, Index number of the next number = the next number in the list, numbers between the number index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween number halfway between the number at index 2 and the number at index 3."

   - A [Data to Assign]: "Metadata to Assign"

   OUTPUTS:
   - O [Object]: "Object"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: Transform > Panel: Morph)

   INPUTS:

   - C0 [Base]: "Base curve"
   - C1 [Target]: "Target curve"
   - R0 [Reverse Base]: "If true, then direction of the base curve is reversed."
   - R1 [Reverse Target]: "If true, then direction of the target curve is reversed."
   - S [Stretch]: "If true, the length of objects along the curve directions is changed to reflect the curve dimensions."
   - R [Rigid]: "Geometry will not be deformed as it is transformed"

   OUTPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Morphed geometry"

## Twisted Box Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted boxes along"
   - X [Size X]: "Domain size of the twisted box curve {x} dimension"
   - Y [Size Y]: "Domain size of the twisted box curve {y} dimension"
   - t [Parameters T]: "Division parameters along curve {t} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - R¹ [Rotation 1]: "Rotation of the twisted box curve around the twisted box centers, in degrees"
   - R² [Rotation 2]: "Rotation of the twisted box curve around the curve, in degrees
(if the twisted box curve is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted boxes along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Strip
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - R¹ [Rail 1]: "Rail curve that the first and fifth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R² [Rail 2]: "Rail curve that the second and sixth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the twisted box strip, offset from the rail curves"
   - t [Parameters T]: "Division parameters along each rail curves {t} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input rail curves curvatures"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting strip twisted boxes"

## Tween Two Surfaces Along Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Surface A]: "Surface along guide curve to tween from"
   - B [Surface B]: "Surface along guide curve to tween to"
   - G¹ [Guide 1]: "Guide curve to tween along (best if flowing from Surface A to Surface B)"
   - G² [Guide 2]: "Optional second guide curve to tween along (best if flowing in the direction of Guide 1)"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface A, 1.0 = Surface B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surface along curve"

----------------------------------------

   - S [Size Factor]: "A multiplier on the scale. Use this to adjust the size of the text in the display."
   - C [Color]: "The color to display the text."
   - D [Depth]: "A value that controls the Z-depth of the text display. 
Higher numbers will appear in front of most objects - lower will go behind.
However, values that are too high may cause the display to disappear completely."
   - A [Absolute]: "If true, text remains a fixed size relative to world dimenions - if false, text is always the same size relative to the screen"

   - UpperCutoff [UpperCutoff]: "spring will only work below this distance; set to 0 for no limit"
   - LowerCutoff [LowerCutoff]: "spring will only work above this distance"
   - Plasticity [Plasticity]: "Maximum elastic deformation (as a factor of rest length). Deformations beyond this amount will alter the rest length of the spring. Set to zero for infinite (fully elastic, with no plasticity)"

   OUTPUTS:

## Mirror Cut Domains
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Domain)

   INPUTS:
   - I [Domains]: "Set of domains to mirror cut"
   - Mi [Mirror Index]: "Index that the kept side of the domain set cut gets mirrored across.
Negative index reverses the domain set and removes from the top."
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (False = Mirror after index, True = Mirror before index)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut domain set (removes the duplicate domain in the middle of the set)"
   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the domain set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut domain set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut domain set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mirror index intersected the domain set, False if the mirror index did not intersect the domain set"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Tube
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array along"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Diameter, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - R [Radius]: "Outer radius of the twisted box tube array"
   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the twisted box tube array, offset inward from the outer radius corners"
   - O [Offset]: "Domain defined offset center location of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve
(0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotation 1]: "Rotation of the twisted box tube array around the radius centers, in degrees"
   - R² [Rotation 2]: "Rotation of the twisted box tube array around the curve, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box tube array along curve"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, numbers between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on curve"

----------------------------------------

## Over Populate an Image
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Populate)

   INPUTS:
   - Image [I]: "Location/Path of image file (BMP, GIF, EXIF, JPG, PNG and TIFF), or Image, or Mesh (from image)"
   - nRb [nRadiusBlack]: "Normalized radius for the black, if 1 it equals the width of the image [1e-4, 1]"
   - nRw [nRadiusWhite]: "Normalized radius for the white, if 1 it equals the width of the image [1e-4, 1]"
   - mC [MaxContrast]: "If true maximalise the contrast"
   - D [Division]: "Circles overpopulation factor [1, 20]"
   - Max [Max]: "Maximum number of points per pixel"
   - S [Seed]: "Seed for the random "

   OUTPUTS:
   - I [Image]: "Image as mesh"
   - C [Circles]: "Circles"
   - Rb [Radius B]: "Radius for the black in real size"
   - Rw [Radius W]: "Radius for the white in real radius"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Consecutive Points On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween points on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P, 1.0 = Point at P +1)"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input point set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween points on surface"

## V-Ray Element Denoiser
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Render Elements)

   INPUTS:
   - Engine [Engine]: "Specifies the denoising engine to use.
The standard V-Ray Denoiser is slower but may be more accurate and can denoise multiple render elements.
The NVIDIA AI denoiser is fast but less accurate. Nvidia GPU is required.
The Intel Open Image denoise is fast and runs on the CPU."
   - Preset [Preset]: "Offers presets to automatically set the strength of the effect.
This parameter is ignored by the NVIDIA AI engine."
   - Mode [Mode]: "Specifies how the results of the Denoiser are saved and presented in the VFB
Show Denoiser Channel – The VRayDenoiser and effectsResult channels are generated
Hide Denoiser Channel – The VRayDenoiser channel is not present separately in the VFB. The effectsResult channel is generated with the denoised image
Only Render Elements – All render elements required for denoising are generated but a denoised version of the image is not computed. Use this option if you plan to denoise a sequence of animation frames using the standalone Denoiser tool. This provides better smoothing between the frames and eliminates any potential flickering."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Element [• Render Element]: "V-Ray Denoiser render element"

----------------------------------------

   - A [Algorithm]: "Type of method used, if 0 Cotan, if 1 Length, if 2 Uniform"
   - B [Boundary]: "If true, values will not change on boundary"
   - U [Unit Vector]: "If true vectors will be perpandicular to the normals and unitized (vector length =1)"
   - N [Steps]: "Number of steps"

## Twisted Box Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to create twisted box array through"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along surface {u} domains ({u}0.0 = Surface starts, {u}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along surface {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Surface starts, {v}1.0 = Surface ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through surfaces {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Surface at S start, {w}1.0 = Surface at S end), unless Normalized is False

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for {w} parameters are ({w}0.0 = Surface at index 0, {w}Index number of last surface = Surface at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last surface, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is evaluated along the interpolation path without considering the locations of the input surface set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input surface set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the parameters {w} interpolation path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the division parameters {w} range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and surface degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the surface by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through surfaces"

----------------------------------------

## Curve Graph Mapper
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Number)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "One or multiple graph curves to graph map values with"
   - R [Rectangle]: "Rectangle which defines the boundary of the graph, graph curves should be atleast partially inside this boundary"
   - V [Values]: "Values to graph map. Values are plotted along the X Axis, intersected with the graph curves, then mapped to the Y Axis"
   - X [X Axis]: "Domain of the graphs X Axis, where the values get plotted (if omitted the input value lists domain bounds is used)"
   - Y [Y Axis]: "Domain of the graphs Y Axis, where the values get mapped to (if omitted the input value lists domain bounds is used)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the graphs X Axis from the bottom of the graph to the top of the graph"
   - S [Snap]: "Resize the graph by snapping it to the extents of the graph curves, in the plane of the boundary rectangle"
   - T [Text Size]: "Size of the graph labels"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mapped]: "Resulting graph mapped values, mapped on the Y Axis"
   - gC [Graph Curves]: "The graph curves inside the boundary of the graph"
   - gP [Graph Points]: "The points on the graph curves where the X Axis input values intersected"
   - vL [Value Lines]: "The lines from the X Axis input values to the graph curves"
   - vP [Value Points]: "The points plotted on the X Axis which represent the input values"
   - mL [Mapped Lines]: "The lines from the graph curves to the Y Axis graph mapped values"
   - mP [Mapped Points]: "The points mapped on the Y Axis which represent the graph mapped values"
   - B [Boundary]: "The graph boundary background as a surface"
   - L [Labels]: "The graph labels as curve outlines"
   - O [Out Of Bounds]: "True for input values outside of the X Axis domain bounds
False for input values inside of the X Axis domain bounds"
   - I [Intersected]: "True for input values on the X Axis which intersect a graph curve
False for input values on the X Axis which do not intersect a graph curve"

----------------------------------------

## Neural Network Trainer
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Accord.net)

   INPUTS:
   - Inputs [Training Inputs]: "The training inputs values"
   - Outputs [Training Outputs]: "The expected outputs values"
   - Hidden Neurons [Hidden Neurons]: "Number of neurons in each hidden layer."
   - Learning Algorithm [Learning Algorithm]: "Learning Algorithm: 
 (0) Backpropagation
 (1) Resilient Backpropagation
 (2) Evolutionary (Genetic) Algorithm
 (3) Levenberg-Marquardt"
   - Activation Function [Activation Function]: "Activation Function: 
 (0) Sigmoid
 (1) Bipolar Sigmoid
 (2) Linear
 (3) Rectified Linear
 (4) Threshold
 (5) Identity"
   - Alpha [Alpha]: "Alpha value."
   - Iterations [Iterations]: "Number of iterations to teach the network."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Neural Network [Trained Nueral Network]: "Trained Neural Network"
   - Error [Error's Dynamics ]: "Error's Dynamics"

----------------------------------------

## Surface Spans
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to get span information of"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S² [Sub-Domain²s]: "Surface sub-domain² for each span that makes up the surface

To extract each span as a separate surface use these as the Domain(D) input on Grasshopper's Isotrim component."
   - uS [Sub-Domain U]: "Domain in {u} direction of each span that makes up the surface"
   - vS [Sub-Domain V]: "Domain in {v} direction of each span that makes up the surface"
   - uA [Amount U]: "Amount of spans in the {u} direction that make up the surface"
   - vA [Amount V]: "Amount of spans in the {v} direction that make up the surface"
   - uL [Lengths U]: "Approximate length in {u} direction of each span that makes up the surface"
   - vL [Lengths V]: "Approximate length in {v} direction of each span that makes up the surface"
   - uD [Degrees U]: "Degree in {u} direction of each span that makes up the surface"
   - vD [Degrees V]: "Degree in {v} direction of each span that makes up the surface"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Parameter in {u} direction of each span isocurve that makes up the surface"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Parameter in {v} direction of each span isocurve that makes up the surface"
   - uv [Parameters UV]: "Surface parameter coordinates at the span ends

To get the point between each span use these as the Point(uv) input on Grasshopper's Evaluate Surface component."

----------------------------------------

## Single Line Fill with Zigzags
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: Print)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "List of planar, non intersecting curves, if curve is open it will be used for the direction of the pattern"
   - W [Print Width]: "Print Width or Offset Distance or Distance between Patterns"
   - B [Relative Bridge Width]: "Bridge Width Factor relative to Print Width"
   - dX [Pattern Length Factor]: "Pattern length factor relative to Print Width"
   - dY [Pattern Height Factor]: "Pattern height factor relative to Print Width"
   - Bo [Use Border Curves]: "If true use the border curves"
   - Sf [Smooth Factor]: "Factor to smooth the Pattern [0, 1["
   - S [Relative Search Distance]: "Search factor relative to Print Width"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance used to convert the curves to polyline"
   - P [Parallel Calculation]: "If true use parallel computation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Polylines]: "Polylines sorted used as borders, first polyline is the outside, others are the holes"
   - Pl [Planes]: "Planes"
   - Pa [Patterns Closed]: "Closed curves patterns"
   - Po [Patterns Opened]: "Opened curves patterns"
   - B [Bridges]: "Bridges"
   - S [Single Line Fill]: "Single line fill, if OK just one polyline"

   (Tab: Human > Panel: Creation)

   INPUTS:

   - C [Curves]: "The sets of curves to hatch. Curves in the same branch will be processed at the same time, producing internal voids where appropriate."
   - N [Hatch Pattern Name]: "The name of the hatch to search for. If left blank or if the specified hatch cannot be found, a solid hatch will be used."
   - S [Hatch Scale]: "Hatch scale"
   - R [Hatch Rotation]: "Hatch rotation in radians"

## Tween Through Vectors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Vector)

   INPUTS:
   - V [Vectors]: "Set of vectors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Vector at V start, 1.0 = Vector at V end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Vector at index 0, Index number of last vector = Vector at last index)

The tween factor range from one vector to the next vector in the list is:
Index number of a vector = the vector at that index, Index number of the next vector = the next vector in the list, factors between the vector index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween vector halfway between the vector at index 2 and the vector at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input vector set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input vector set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween vector"

----------------------------------------

## Regression Tester
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Models)

   INPUTS:
   - Model [Model]: "Trained Regression model."
   - Testing Data [Testing Data Set]: "The testing data set."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Predictions [Predictions]: "Predictions"
   - R2 [R2]: "R-squared (R2, also known as the coefficient of determination, represents the predictive power of the model as a value between -inf and 1.00. 1.00 means there is a perfect fit, and the fit can be arbitrarily poor so the scores can be negative. A score of 0.00 means the model is guessing the expected value for the label. R2 measures how close the actual test data values are to the predicted values."
   - Abs Loss [Absolute Loss]: "Absolute loss, also known as the Mean absolute error (MAE), measures how close the predictions are to the actual outcomes. It is the average of all the model errors, where model error is the absolute distance between the predicted label value and the correct label value. This prediction error is calculated for each record of the test data set. Finally, the mean value is calculated for all recorded absolute errors."
   - Sq Loss [Squared Loss]: "Squared loss, also known as Mean square error (MSE) or Mean squared deviation (MSD), tells you how close a regression line is to a set of test data values by taking the distances from the points to the regression line (these distances are the errors E) and squaring them. The squaring gives more weight to larger differences."
   - RMS Loss [Root Mean Squared Loss]: "Root mean squared error (RMSE) measures the difference between values predicted by a model and the values observed from the environment that is being modeled. RMS-loss is the square root of Squared-loss and has the same units as the label, similar to the absolute-loss though giving more weight to larger differences."

----------------------------------------

## Round To Nearest
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Number)

   INPUTS:
   - x [Numbers X]: "Set of numbers to round"
   - y [Numbers Y]: "Set of numbers to round nearest to (best to not have duplicate y values)"
   - R [Remap x]: "Remap number set x to the domain bounds of number set y"

   OUTPUTS:
   - N [Nearest]: "Resulting numbers in y nearest to each number in x (if Remap(R) is set to true then numbers in y nearest to each remapped number x)"
   - i [Index]: "Index of number in y nearest to each number in x (if Remap(R) is set to true then index of number in y nearest to each remapped number in x)"
   - D [Difference]: "The difference between the resulting nearest number set and the input number set x"
   - xR [Remapped x]: "Remapped number set x to the domain bounds of number set y if Remap(R) is true. Same number as number set x if Remap(R) is false"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Consecutive Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:

   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters between each meshes {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Mesh at M, {w}1.0 = Mesh at M +1)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between meshes"

## Tween Through Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P start, 1.0 = Point at P end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input point set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input point set and the tween path curvature"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point"

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

## Weighted Average Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves for averaging"
   - W [Weights]: "Collection of weights for each curve"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped averages, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped averages, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input curves"

----------------------------------------

## Gears
   (Tab: Kangaroo > Panel: Utility)

   INPUTS:
   - D [Driver]: "The input gear"
   - F [Follower]: "The gear which is affected by the driver"
   - A [Axle]: "The point about which the Follower gear rotates. Moving this during simulation will move the gear along with it"
   - C [Compound]: "An optional curve (or list of curves) to attach to the movement of the follower gear, but not itself be affected by the driver"
   - P [Pull]: "Option for whether to pull the curves together"
   - R [Reset]: "Set to true to bring curves back to original locations"

   OUTPUTS:
   - F [Follower]: "The gear which is affected by the driver"
   - C [Compound]: "Compound gears output"
   - A [Angle]: "The rotation between the input and output Follower curve"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Light Rig Sun System
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Lighting)

   INPUTS:
   - On [On]: "Enables or disables the light source."
   - Position [Position]: "Light source location (point position).
If a list of input Positions is connected multiple lights will be generated.
Note: The number of input positions will determine the lights count."
   - Target [Target]: "The light Position and Target combined determine the targeted light orientation vector."
   - Intensity [Intensity]: "Light source intensity. Calculated in the specified units."
   - Filter Color [Filter Color]: "Tints the automatic Sun light color. Note that the light color also depends on the Sun's altitude."
   - Ground Color [Ground Color]: "The Ground Albedo color."
   - Caustics Radius [Caustics Emit Radius]: "Defines the area around the V-Ray Sun from where the photons will be shot."
   - Caustics Subdivs [Caustics Subdivisions]: "Determines the number of caustic photons emitted from the light source.
Lower values mean more noisy results, but will render faster.
Higher values produce smoother results but take more time."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Light [• Add Light]: "Light output that can be connected to a Renderer"
   - • Env [• Environment]: "V-Ray Environment to be plugged into the renderer"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Extrude
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Profile]: "Profile curve or surface to extrude as twisted boxes

Profile should preferably be a quadrilateral polygon (4 sided polyline with 4 corners). If profile is not a quadrilateral polygon it will be converted. Profile does not need to be planar or closed. Triangles are acceptable."
   - D [Direction]: "Extrusion direction vector, curve, or point

Input a vector to exrude along a vector
Input a curve to exrude along a curve
Input a point to extrude to a point"
   - t [Parameters T]: "Division parameters along the extrusion {t} domain (0.0 = Extrusion start, 1.0 = Extrusion end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, the parameters {t} input is used as normalized lengths (0.5 = Extrusion middle).
If False, the parameters {t} input is used as extrusion parameters. (0.5 = Domain middle)."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting extruded twisted boxes"

----------------------------------------

## Filter by User Attributes
   (Tab: eleFront > Panel: 02 Filter)

   INPUTS:
   - []K [Key]: "Key to match with referenced objects. Connect ValueList for possible keys."
   - V [Val]: "Value to match with referenced objects."
   - A [Attributes]: "Attributes/Referenced Geometry to evaluate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Filtered Object(s)"

## Reduce Mesh
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to reduce"
   - F [Face Count]: "Target face count. This number is just a target goal, face count in resulting reduced mesh may differ"
   - A [Accuracy]: "Accuracy of reduction (1 = Least, 10 = Most)"
   - T [Face Type]: "0 = Default (face types are a direct result of the reduction)
1 = Quadrangulate if possible (gets applied after reduction, may change face count)
2 = Triangulate all (gets applied after reduction, may change face count)"
   - D [Distort]: "If true, mesh will reduce to reach the desired face count
If false, mesh will reduce only until the point at which the mesh shape would be required to change"
   - N [Normalize]: "More equally distribute the mesh face sizes"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Reduced]: "Resulting reduced mesh"
   - C [Count Difference]: "Difference in face count between the original mesh and the reduced mesh"

----------------------------------------

(0.0 to 0.0 = on curve)"

## Tween Through Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Mesh at index 0, Index number of last mesh = Mesh at last index)

The tween factor range from one mesh to the next mesh in the list is:
Index number of a mesh = the mesh at that index, Index number of the next mesh = the next mesh in the list, numbers between the mesh index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween mesh halfway between the mesh at index 2 and the mesh at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween mesh"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on surface to tween between"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index), unless Normalized is true

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - N [Normalized]: "If True, use a normalized tween factor (Factor 0.0 = Point at P start, Factor 1.0 = Point at P end)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on surface"

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at Pl start, 1.0 = Plane at Pl end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, factors between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input plane set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input plane set and the tween path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the tween path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane"

----------------------------------------

## Multiclass Classifier Trainer
   (Tab: LunchBoxML > Panel: Models)

   INPUTS:
   - Training Data [Training Data Set]: "The training data set."
   - Features [Feature Names]: "The names of the columns in the data set to be categorized as features. The inputs to a machine learning model are called features."
   - Label [Label Name]: "The name of the column in the data set to be categorized as the label. The ground-truth values (sometimes known as outputs) are used to train a machine learning model are called labels."
   - Trainer Type [Trainer Type]: "The type of trainer used for multiclass classification."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Model [Model]: "Trained Model"

----------------------------------------

   - N [Samples]: "Number of samples (parts of curve on mesh)"
   - D [Direction]: "Direction of flow, 0 for flow along vector, 1 for flow opposite to vector, 2 for both directions merged in one curve following the vectors"
   - T [Tolerance]: "A tolerance used to suppress close points"

Sections should preferably be quadrilateral polygons (4 sided polylines with 4 corners). If sections are not quadrilateral polygons they will be converted. Sections do not need to be planar or closed. Triangles are acceptable."

## Twisted Box Through Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to create twisted box array through"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters through meshes {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Mesh at M start, {w}1.0 = Mesh at M end), unless Normalized is False

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for {w} parameters are ({w}0.0 = Mesh at index 0, {w}Index number of last mesh = Mesh at last index)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and the index of the last mesh, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is evaluated along the interpolation path without considering the locations of the input mesh set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {w} distribution is weighted by the input mesh set and the interpolation path curvature"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the parameters {w} interpolation path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the division parameters {w} range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the {w} interpolation path, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {w} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array through meshes"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Surfaces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surfaces]: "Set of surfaces to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Surface at index 0, Index number of last surface = Surface at last index)

The tween factor range from one surface to the next surface in the list is:
Index number of a surface = the surface at that index, Index number of the next surface = the next surface in the list, numbers between the surface index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween surface halfway between the surface at index 2 and the surface at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input surfaces are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the surfaces curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points per direction) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input surfaces are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing each direction by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween surface"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:

   - T [Close Type]: "Determines how the curve is closed

0 = Linear
1 = Tangency
2 = Curvature
3 = Meet Ends"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for curve closing segment"
   - t [Tolerance]: "Optional allowable distance between start and end of curve.
If gap is larger than tolerance the curve will not close.
If tolerance is 0.0 the curve will close no matter the gap size."

   OUTPUTS:
   - C [Closed]: "Resulting closed curve"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if open curve was closed, False if curve did not close or already was closed"

## Unsplit Sweep Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   - R¹ [Rail 1]: "Rail curve to sweep along (best if flowing from first Section in S to last Section in S)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Unsplit]: "Resulting untrimmed single unsplit swept surface

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component."

## Geodesics Point To Point
   (Tab: Nautilus > Panel: CurveOnMesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh"
   - Pfrom [Point From]: "Departure point"
   - Pto [Point To]: "Arrival point"
   - S [SmoothMesh]: "Tell if angle is from smooth mesh or face normal"
   - D [Divisions]: "Number of initials paths on a fan of 360° [8, 1000]"
   - N [Iterations]: "Maximum number of iterations [0,100]"
   - M [MiddleAngle]: "If true next path is at middle angle of a fan"
   - T [Tolerance]: "Tolerance [1e-8, x]"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Path]: "Minimum length geodesic"
   - L [Length]: "Geodesic minimum path length"
   - Ps [Paths]: "Geodesics"

----------------------------------------

0 = Normal
1 = Loose
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform
4 = Straight"

   OUTPUTS:

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component"

## Tween Two Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Curve A]: "Curve to tween from"
   - B [Curve B]: "Curve to tween to"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve A, 1.0 = Curve B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve"

----------------------------------------

## Set Precision
   (Tab: Pancake > Panel: 03 | Quantity)

   INPUTS:
   - Q [Quantity]: "Quantity"
   - P [Precision]: "Precision.
For decimal quantities, the precision is how many digits are preserved after the decimal point.
For feet and inch length, the precision is the minimal fraction to be preserved. e.g. Precision = 64 will yield 1 / 64 as the smallest stepping. Precision doesn't need to be a power of two."

   OUTPUTS:
   - Q [Adjusted Quantity]: "Adjusted Quantity"
   - L? [Lost Accuracy?]: "Return if internal accuracy has lost during precision resetting.
If the accuracy is not lost, you can fully return to the original value by raising the precision of the adjusted quantity (use this component again). Otherwise you cannot."

## Average Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves for averaging"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped averages, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped averages, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - AM [Arithmetic mean]: "Arithmetic mean (average) of all input curves"

----------------------------------------

   - K [Kill]: "Kill coefficient"

   - N [Number of iterations]: "Number of iterations"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Colored Mesh]: "Colored Mesh with A as Red and B as green"

## Blend Through Meshes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Meshes]: "Set of meshes to blend through"
   - F [Factors]: "Blend factors, one factor for each set of vertices which share the same vertex index across the meshes
(0.0 = Mesh at M start vertices, 1.0 = Mesh at M end vertices), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Mesh at index 0 vertices, Index number of last mesh = Mesh at last index vertices)

The blend factor range from one mesh's vertices to the next mesh's vertices in the list is:
Index number of a mesh = the vertices of the mesh at that index, Index number of the next mesh = the vertices of the next mesh in the list, factors between the mesh index numbers will be the corresponding mesh vertex blends.

For instance:
A blend factor of 2.5 will result in blend mesh vertices halfway between the mesh at index 2's vertices and a mesh at index 3's vertices."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, blend distribution is evaluated along the vertex blend paths without considering the locations of the input mesh sets vertices"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, blend distribution is weighted by the input mesh sets vertices and the vertex blend paths curvatures"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the blend path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the blend factor range maximum by 1)"
   - D [Degree]: "Curvature degree of the vertex blend paths, degree should be a positive odd number"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the vertex blend paths are interpolated

0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - C [Colored Type]: "Determines how mesh vertex colors are blended

0 = None
1 = Fast
2 = Accurate"

   OUTPUTS:
   - B [Blend]: "Resulting blend mesh"

----------------------------------------

   (Tab: Mesh > Panel: Primitive)

   INPUTS:
   - B [Base]: "Base plane"
   - W [Width]: "Domain of width"
   - H [Height]: "Domain of height"
   - Cw [Width count]: "Number of faces along {x} direction"

When true, separators within double quotes are treated as part of the input value. When false, all separators, even those within quotes, are treated as delimiting a new column."

0: Fixed. Naked edges will not move or be modified.
1: Smooth. The naked edge will tend toward a spline.
2: Corner Fixed. Corners (2-sided vertices) will be fixed, while other naked vertices will tend toward a spline.
"

## Tween Through Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves on surface to tween through"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curve on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C start, 1.0 = Curve at C end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Curve at index 0, Index number of last curve = Curve at last index)

The tween factor range from one curve to the next curve in the list is:
Index number of a curve = the curve at that index, Index number of the next curve = the next curve in the list, factors between the curve index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween curve halfway between the curve at index 2 and the curve at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the tween path without considering the locations of the input curve set"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the tween path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop
(if Normalized is False, increase the tween factor range maximum by 1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the tween path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve on surface"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Points
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the point set cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Points within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept points from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the point set and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut point set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index

To split the mirror cut point set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the point set was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the point set was not intersected by the mirror cut"

## Twisted Box Strip Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - R¹ [Rail 1]: "Rail curve that the first and fourth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R² [Rail 2]: "Rail curve that the second and third corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - T [Thickness]: "Thickness of the twisted box strip, offset from the rail curves"
   - t¹ [Parameters T1]: "Division parameters along rail curve one's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 1 start, 1.0 = Rail 1 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the parameters {t} t¹ list"
   - t² [Parameters T2]: "Division parameters along rail curve two's {t} domain (0.0 = Rail 2 start, 1.0 = Rail 2 end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, non duplicate, and have the same amount of parameters as the parameters {t} t² list"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input rail curves curvatures"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting strip twisted boxes"

## Mirror Cut Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Colors]: "Set of colors to mirror cut"
   - Mi [Mirror Index]: "Index that the kept side of the color set cut gets mirrored across.
Negative index reverses the color set and removes from the top."
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction (false = Mirror after index, true = Mirror before index)"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut color set (removes the duplicate color in the middle of the set)"
   - T [Mirror Type]: "Determines how the color set is mirrored

0 = Reflected
1 = Inverted"
   - a [Alpha]: "Invert the transparencies (alpha values) of the mirrored colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut color set"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut color set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the mirror index intersected the color set, False if the mirror index did not intersect the color set"

1 = Floor (The closest length smaller than or equal to the target length)

## Reduce Mesh By Faces
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Mesh)

   INPUTS:
   - M [Mesh]: "Mesh to reduce"
   - F [Face Count]: "Target face count. This number is just a target goal, face count in resulting reduced mesh may differ"
   - A [Accuracy]: "Accuracy of reduction (1 = Least, 10 = Most)"
   - T [Face Type]: "0 = Default (face types are a direct result of the reduction)
1 = Quadrangulate if possible (gets applied after reduction, may change face count)
2 = Triangulate all (gets applied after reduction, may change face count)"
   - D [Distort]: "If true, mesh will reduce to reach the desired face count
If false, mesh will reduce only until the point at which the mesh shape would be required to change"
   - N [Normalize]: "More equally distribute the mesh face sizes"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Reduced]: "Resulting reduced mesh"
   - C [Count Difference]: "Difference in face count between the original mesh and the reduced mesh"

   (Tab: Wombat > Panel: Surface)

   - S [South Edge]: "Length to extend south edge (0 for no extension)"
   - E [East Edge]: "Length to extend east edge (0 for no extension)"
   - N [North Edge]: "Length to extend north edge (0 for no extension)"
   - T [Extension Type]: "Set True for smooth extension, False for ruled"

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Extended surface"

----------------------------------------

You may use Object attributes from Elefront, or Human.
See manual for supported attributes."
   - File [File Location]: "Where to store the file. Filename and extension should be included."
   - Overwrite [Overwrite]: "Default false. Control if Pancake should overwrite the destination file."
   - Opt [Options]: "Options of export. You can either feed it with option templates, or manual input, or leave it unset."
   - PreOpt [Pre-Options]: "General options of export. Connect Rhino file options to this input if needed."
   - Export [Export]: "Set to True to conduct the export. Use True - only button or Toggle button. Do not use the vanilla button."

## Twisted Box Sweep
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - R¹ [Rail 1]: "Rail curve that the first and fourth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R² [Rail 2]: "Rail curve that the second and third corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R³ [Rail 3]: "Rail curve that the sixth and seventh corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - R⁴ [Rail 3]: "Rail curve that the fifth and eighth corners of the twisted boxes are on"
   - t [Parameters T]: "Division parameters along each rail curves {t} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {t} distribution is weighted by the input rail curves curvatures"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting sweep twisted boxes"

## Tween Consecutive Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to tween between"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve at C, 1.0 = Curve at C +1)"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(False = Off, True = On)

If true, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature without changing their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Sample Point]: "Optional Sample Point match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Sample Point match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing by the input integer. Sample point results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curves"

----------------------------------------

## Twisted Box Consecutive Curves
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "Set of curves to create twisted box array between"
   - T [Thickness]: "Overall thickness of the twisted box array, offset from the curves"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters between each curves {u} domain ({u}0.0 = Curve at C, {u}1.0 = Curve at C +1)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters along curve {v} domains ({v}0.0 = Curve starts, {v}1.0 = Curve ends)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain ({w}0.0 = Curves, {w}1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {v} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvatures"
   - L [Loopback]: "If True, allow the parameters {u} interpolation path to continue from the end back to the start as a closed loop"
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "Determines how the {u} interpolation path is interpolated

0 = Straight
1 = Normal
2 = Tight
3 = Uniform"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped twisted boxes, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped twisted boxes, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box array consecutively between curves"

----------------------------------------

 1) Default
 2) Error
 3) Log Loss
 4) None"

   - Sigmoid [Sigmoid Parameter]: "Determines the steepness of the sigmoid function"
   - Use Softmax [Use SoftMax]: "Determines whether to use the SoftMax loss function. The SoftMax function is a generalization of the logistic function to multiple dimensions."
   - Max Bins [Max Bins Per Feature]: "The maximum number of bins that feature values will be bucketed in. A small number of bins may reduce training accuracy but may increase general power (deal with over-fitting)."

   OUTPUTS:

## Twisted Box Tube Variable
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to create twisted box tube array along"
   - R [Radii]: "A list of outer radii for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter"
   - T [Thicknesses]: "A list of thicknesses for the twisted box tube array at every {u} division parameter, offset inward from the outer radius corners"
   - u [Parameters U]: "Division parameters along curve {u} domain (0.0 = Curve start, 1.0 = Curve end)

For best results {u} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - v [Parameters V]: "Division parameters around curve {v} domain (0.0 = Revolve min, 1.0 = Revolve max)

For best results {v} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - w [Parameters W]: "Division parameters along thickness {w} domain (0.0 = Radii, 1.0 = Thickness)

For best results {w} parameters should be between 0 and 1, in numerical order, and non duplicate"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, parameters {u} distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"
   - O [Offsets]: "A list of domain defined offset center locations of the twisted box tube array in relation to the curve at every {u} division parameter (0.0 to 0.0 = centered on curve)"
   - R¹ [Rotations 1]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the radii centers at every {u} division parameter, in degrees"
   - R¹ [Rotations 2]: "A list of rotations of the twisted box tube array around the curve at every {u} division parameter, in degrees
(if the twisted box tube array is centered on the curve the effect will look the same as rotation 1)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Resulting twisted box pipe array along curve"

## Edge Unsplit Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - E [Edges]: "Set of 2, 3, or 4 edge curves to create the edge surface between"

   OUTPUTS:
   - U [Unsplit]: "Resulting untrimmed single unsplit edge surface

When you bake this surface into Rhino it will become a usual polysurface(Brep) which is split at its kinks if it has kinks, unless you first run the command CreaseSplitting in Rhino's command line and turn it off by switching it to No. If this surface has kinks you can turn it into a polysurface(Brep) using Pufferfish's Split Kinky Surface component"

----------------------------------------

   - Rnd [Render]: "Set to true to render with the current renderer. If using V-Ray, be sure to set the v-ray settings to "Batch"."

0 = Reflected

## Tween Through Planes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Plane)

   INPUTS:
   - Pl [Planes]: "Set of planes to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Plane at index 0, Index number of last plane = Plane at last index)

The tween factor range from one plane to the next plane in the list is:
Index number of a plane = the plane at that index, Index number of the next plane = the next plane in the list, numbers between the plane index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween plane halfway between the plane at index 2 and the plane at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - Q [Quaternion]: "Interpolate with quaternion rotation"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween plane"

----------------------------------------

## Mirror Cut Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to mirror cut"
   - MP [Mirror Plane]: "Plane that the kept side of the surface cut gets mirrored across"
   - R [Reach]: "Parts of the surface within this distance from the mirror plane will be additionally cut away"
   - O [Offset]: "Distance to offset the kept parts of the surface from the mirror plane (or offset from the reach if reach in not zero)"
   - F [Flip]: "Flip the mirror direction"
   - J [Join]: "Join the mirror cut surfaces"
   - K [Keep]: "Keep the surface and mirror it normally if it is mirror cut into non-existence"
   - T [Connection Type]: "Determines how the mirror cut surfaces are connected

0 = Linear
1 = Tangency
2 = Curvature
3 = None"
   - B [Bulge]: "Bulge factor for the mirror cut surface connections (-B = Negative Bulge, 0.0 = No Bulge, +B = Positive Bulge)"

   OUTPUTS:
   - M [Mirror Cut]: "Resulting mirror cut surfaces"
   - i [Split Index]: "The splitting index (only if Join is false)

To split the mirror cut surface set at the mirror use this as the index input on Grasshopper's Split List component."
   - RP [Reach Plane]: "The plane at the reach distance"
   - OP [Offset Plane]: "The plane at the offset distance"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the surface was intersected by the mirror cut, False if the surface was not intersected by the mirror cut"

----------------------------------------

## Rotate World
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Transform)

   INPUTS:
   - G [Geometry]: "Geometry to rotate"
   - Pl [Plane]: "Intial base plane which defines the {x}, {y}, and {z} world axes"
   - A¹ [Axis 1]: "The first plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - A² [Axis 2]: "The second plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - A³ [Axis 3]: "The third plane axis to rotate around, derived from the inital base plane

0 = {x} of the inital base plane
1 = {y} of the inital base plane
2 = {z} of the inital base plane"
   - D¹ [Degrees 1]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 1"
   - D² [Degrees 2]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 2"
   - D³ [Degrees 3]: "The angle in degrees to rotate around axis 3"

   OUTPUTS:
   - R [Rotated]: "Resulting rotated geometry"
   - Pl¹ [Plane 1]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 1 (axis 1 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - Pl² [Plane 2]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 2 (axis 2 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - Pl³ [Plane 3]: "The plane after the rotation around axis 3 (axis 3 is an axis from the initial base plane)"
   - X [Transform]: "Transformation data"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Points On Curve
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Point)

   INPUTS:
   - P [Points]: "Set of points on curve to tween through"
   - C [Curve]: "Curve to tween point on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Point at P start, 1.0 = Point at P end), unless Normalized is False"
   - N [Normalized]: "If False, the rules for factor are (0.0 = Point at index 0, Index number of last point = Point at last index)

The tween factor range from one point to the next point in the list is:
Index number of a point = the point at that index, Index number of the next point = the next point in the list, factors between the point index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween point halfway between the point at index 2 and the point at index 3."
   - E [Equalized]: "If True, tween distribution is evaluated along the curve between the point extremes without considering the locations of the input point set"
   - W [Weighted]: "If True, tween distribution is weighted by the input curves curvature"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween point on curve"

----------------------------------------

   INPUTS:

   - Strength [Strength]: "Negative for attraction, Positive for repulsion"
   - Cutoff [Cutoff]: "If positive, the force only works below this distance; if negative only above this distance; and if 0 it works at all distances"

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Power Law]: "Power Law out"

## Shrink Trimmed Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Surface)

   INPUTS:
   - S [Surface]: "Shrinks the underlying untrimmed surface of a trimmed surface to be as close as possible to the trimmed surface edges, also works with polysurface (Brep) faces."

   OUTPUTS:
   - S [Shrunken]: "Resulting trimmed surface (or polysurface (Brep)) with shrunken underlying untrimmed surface"
   - U [Underlying]: "The shrunken underlying untrimmed surface of the trimmed surface (or polysurface (Brep))"
   - R [Result Boolean]: "True if the trimmed surface's underlying untrimmed surface shrank
False if the trimmed surface's underlying untrimmed surface was already shrunk or the input surface was untrimmed"

----------------------------------------

## Polysurface Boolean Twisted Boxes
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Twisted Box)

   INPUTS:
   - TB [Twisted Boxes]: "Set of twsisted boxes to trim"
   - Ps [Polysurfaces]: "Closed polysurface(Brep) or polysurfaces(Breps) to trim with"
   - B [Boolean Type]: "True for boolean intersection (Trim away twisted boxes outside of the polysurface(Brep) or polysurfaces(Breps))
False for boolean difference (Trim away twisted boxes inside of the polysurface(Brep) or polysurfaces(Breps))"
   - K [Keep Type]: "Determines how much of the trimmed twisted box set to keep

0 = Complete (keep if twisted box is completely to the keep side of the polysurface(Brep))
1 = Halfway (keep if twisted box is atleast halfway to the keep side of the polysurface(Brep)) (fastest)
2 = Partial (keep if twisted box is atleast partially to the keep side of the polysurface(Brep))"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Trimmed]: "Resulting trimmed twisted box set"
   - i [Kept Indicies]: "Indices from the input twisted box set of the twisted boxes that remained after the trimming"
   - I [Intersected]: "True if the twisted box set was trimmed, False if the twisted box set was not trimmed"

----------------------------------------

## Tween Through Colors
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Color)

   INPUTS:
   - C [Colors]: "Set of colors to tween through"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Color at index 0, Index number of last color = Color at last index)

The tween factor range from one color to the next color in the list is:
Index number of a color = the color at that index, Index number of the next color = the next color in the list, numbers between the color index numbers will be the corresponding tweens.

For instance:
A tween factor of 2.5 will result in a tween color halfway between the color at index 2 and the color at index 3."
   - I [Interpolation Type]: "0 = Linear
1 = Chord
2 = Square Root
3 = Uniform"
   - a [Alpha]: "Tween the transparencies (alpha values) of the colors"

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween color"

----------------------------------------

## V-Ray Spline Scattering
   (Tab: V-Ray > Panel: Scatter)

   INPUTS:
   - Spacing [Spacing]: "Determines the spacing between instances in world units."
   - Jitter [Jitter]: "Randomly jitters instances along the spline. Each instance has ‘Spacing’ applied on both of its sides, except the instances at the end of the spline. The Jitter value is divided between those two spacings. In order to allow instances to jitter in all their Spacing distance, the Jitter value needs to be set to 2."
   - Offset [Offset]: "Determines what proportion of the ‘Spacing’ value instances are offset in one direction of the spline. When set to 1, all instances replace the one after them, as the offset is equal to the whole value of the ‘Spacing’ parameter."
   - Follow Spline [Follow Spline]: "Determines how scattered instances are oriented along the spline. Assigning a value of 1 makes instances follow the spline and orients them along the local tangent direction."

   OUTPUTS:
   - • Scattering [• Scattering Configuration]: "Configuration data specifying surface scattering mode. Can be connected to the V-Ray Scatter 2 component’s ‘Scattering Configuration’ input."

----------------------------------------

## MultiPipe

   INPUTS:
   - C [Curves]: "The curves to pipe. Also accepts meshes"
   - N [NodeSize]: "Pipe radius. If one value given, it is applied to all. Alternatively, provide a list of radii corresponding to each point in SizePoints"
   - SP [SizePoints]: "If you are supplying multiple radii for NodeSize, these points identify which node to set as which radius. If only some of the nodes have their radius set this way, the values will be interpolated across the shape"
   - E [EndOffset]: "The distance of the first edge loop away from the node as a multiplier of NodeSize. If this is set to zero, no intermediate edge loop is added, to give a smoother shape."
   - SS [StrutSize]: "The size of the struts between nodes as a multiplier of NodeSize. <1 gives tapering struts, >1 gives bulging struts"
   - S [Segment]: "Approximate spacing of edge loops along each strut. If set to zero, no additional edge loops are added"
   - KA [KinkAngle]: "When the input to 'Curves' are smooth curves, this sets the maximum angle between consecutive segments when discretizing"
   - CF [CubeFit]: "If >0 this attempts to fit a cube at each node. Should be a value between 0 and 1, where 0 = never, and 1 = always, depending on how close to orthogonal its connected lines are."

   OUTPUTS:
   - P [Pipe]: "Resulting Pipe SubD"

----------------------------------------

## Tangent Arcs
   (Tab: Curve > Panel: Primitive)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Circle A]: "First base circle"
   - B [Circle B]: "Second base circle"
   - R [Radius]: "Radius of tangent arcs"

   OUTPUTS:
   - A [Arc A]: "First tangent arc solution"
   - B [Arc B]: "Second tangent arc solution"

## Tween Two Curves On Surface
   (Tab: Pufferfish > Panel: Curve)

   INPUTS:
   - A [Curve A]: "Curve on surface to tween from"
   - B [Curve B]: "Curve on surface to tween to"
   - S [Surface]: "Surface to tween curve on"
   - F [Factor]: "Tween factor (0.0 = Curve A, 1.0 = Curve B)"
   - R [Refit]: "Optional Refit match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and curve degree of refit)

If an integer greater than zero, Refit match method is used if possible. When input curves are refit their control points are redistributed, added to, and removed from based on the curves curvature and the input integer degree, while trying to maintain their shapes. Refit results in tighter shaped tweens, with curvature based control point distribution."
   - P [Point Sample]: "Optional Point Sample match method.
(No Integer or 0 = Off, Integer greater than 0 = On and amount of sample points) 

If an integer greater than zero, Point Sample match method is used. When input curves are sampled their control points are recreated by equally dividing the curve by the input integer point count. Point Sample results in looser shaped tweens, with uniform control point distribution."

   OUTPUTS:
   - T [Tween]: "Resulting tween curve on surface"

----------------------------------------
